reviewText:
Mayday, mayday, oh stuff it, HEEEEELP...
You've crashed. On a planet. It's a planet made up of wierd and strange things, creatures that up until your arrival quite likely existed in peace and harmony, and then you brought yourself, your mass of crates which have scattered around the landscape, and the teleporters you so desperately need to get back to your now scuffed up transport ship to get out of dodge.

Whilst on the surface the game is very much a case of guns blazing and murder everything in sight, as you dig into the lore and entries of the game, what you'll learn is that the planet was more or less *fine* until the ship crashlanded, spewed it's cargo all over the shop and you, in your size twelves and large caliber weapons, decided to cut a swathe through the landscape to get out.

Congratulations, you are the risk of rain the locals keep talking about. Don't you feel just awesome?

Tightly tuned, finely balanced, class based roguelite gameplay...
Starting the game the first time gives you access to the beginner class - Commando. This class is a good place to learn how to deal with the game, and a balanced set of skills that should see you progress at a reasonable rate. All the unlockable classes are tailored towards specific styles of play, and generally require specialist approaches to get the most out of them. A good example is the enforcer, which is far slower and less mobile than the commando, but due to his riot shield, can essentially soak -ridiculous- quantities of damage from the direction he's facing.

Later classes are even more specialised, opening up classes that work from afar, or specialise in deployables or traps, or have other means of dealing with situations. In short, every class feels unique, and has their own combos and specific ways to work things out. Furthermore, with the items that you can collect, every class will evolve differently based on the drops you find. The Enforcer in one playthrough will be an entirely different Enforcer in the next. Even if there are some items you'll ideally want to grab each time.

The importance of good design and a great soundtrack
The graphics might be pixel art, which by this stage you'd think have been done to death, but on the contrary, the clear, concise design and the very well thought out vision ensure that this game always looks stylish and well presented. This is a game that revels in looking good, and always ensures that the player is in control of what's going on, even when there's a -lot- going on at once.

Combined with the precise and well balanced combat, along with the great sense of atmosphere, is potentially one of the best soundtracks of recent times, going alongside things such as Don't Starve, Deus Ex : Human Revolution, and Really Big Sky. A good soundtrack sells the atmosphere, and in this case it's been captured perfectly, possibly one of the best soundtracks in my library.

Deep replayability and a stellar atmosphere combined
Risk of rain was one of my top picks when I bought it, this has not changed and it still remains one of the greatest games available on steam. Along with the legends like FTL, like Dungeons of Dredmor, Risk of Rain should be considered essential gaming for anyone who wants to get their hands into the genre of Roguelites" that contains things like Spelunky and co.

Verdict : Essential

Writer and columnist for Just Reviews

reviewText:
Stop adding me without even saying anything. Jesus Christ have some decency
serious review? serious review.
Risk of Rain is an extremely addictive arcade style 2D platformer shoot-em-up with roguelike elements.

Gameplay consists of dying a lot attempting to reach and activate the stage exit teleporter in each level, there are a total of 6 levels to complete per game before achieving TOTAL VICTORY

Online Co-Op, many characters with their own unique playstyle, randomly generated level layouts, and loads of items keep gameplay fresh and exciting so you can just get goat hooves and syringes and win instantly

Gameplay

Tight, responsive controls and enough characters to pick a playstyle that you enjoy make this an incredibly fun and rewarding experience.

Graphics

A charming, simple artstyle with smooth animations makes this game a treat for the eyes.

Sound

An expertly done soundtrack brings a LOT to the table, sound quality is good, sound effects aren't obnoxious.

Story

A very ambigous story, no definite answers are given, but clues are relayed through item logs and monster descriptions.

Multiplayer?

This game features both local and online co-op, the co-op system (especially online) is a bit excruciatingly buggy, but very fun to play with friends.

Fun?

The artstyle, gameplay, and unpredictability of this game make for an extremely enjoyable time.

reviewText:
Beautiful, sophisticated, yet brutal. Yes, like your new girlfriend, Risk of Rain is a ball of wonderment and pain.

In this rogue-like platformer, you run around each level trying to find a teleporter. Meanwhile, enemies spawn randomly; killing them gives you gold with which you can open containers with upgrades for your character. Once you find a teleporter, you fight a boss and ultimately move on to the next level.

The catch? The longer you play, the tougher the enemies become! So speed is of the essence as well as quick reflexes and mob management.

The artstyle for this game is pixel based, and it's wonderful how much character these little sprites have! The tiny animations are smooth, and watching an enemy explode into blocks of meat chunks is satisfying.

The music is also fantastic; it's a hauntin track that sounds like a dubstep/trance hybrid one moment and a thumping bass the next.

And the gameplay: oh boy, is this game tough! But you come out of it a better man (or woman) with blistered fingers and a beard on her knuckles (that goes for the women too).

So this game comes highly recommended! There are a lot of achievements/unlockables including new items and classes, so the replay value is truly up there. Do yourself a favor and pick up Risk of Rain!

reviewText:
Risk of Rain is an action platformer with some roguelike elements. It features beautiful pixel art and a great soundtrack. Besides singleplayer, you can enjoy it in local or online co-op mode. Oh, yeah, it's also pretty hard and unforgiving.

You take a role of a space train crash survivor that ends up on a mysterious planet. Your goal is to find teleporters scattered around the planet and eventually get off it and save yourself. Only thing standing between you and salvation are hordes of different enemies and dozens of giant bosses that don't seem to appreciate your sudden visit.

There are 10 classes to choose from but only 1 is available at start. Others are unlocked through various achievements. Some work better than others but they offer enough variety and present you with different challenges which is always fun. Each class has 4 different skills where 1 is actually their basic attack (melee or ranged).

To help you in your adventure there is also a big collection of items with interesting and fun effects. They are located in chests which were your crashed train's cargo. The chests are randomly scattered around proceduraly generated levels and it is your job to find them. Just don't take too long because the game gets harder as the time goes by.

Combat is what makes this game great. The controls are rather simple and I don't have any problems using a keyboard to play Risk of Rain.

Risk of Rain wants everything of you but being static. You will have to constantly move to scout the level and find items or a teleporter anyway, but mostly to dodge the incoming attacks like bites from lizzard-like sentient species or avoid getting zapped by flying jellyfish.

Later on, you will realise you don't have to spam jump button and just run in the opposite direction of monsters and pray. You will listen for audio ques or learn the timing of enemy atacks enabling you to time your jumps and dodges, that you can use higher ground against enemies that can't climb etc.

Sometimes the game will throw you a curve ball (or a fun ball depending how you look at it) in a form of elite monsters. They are beefier than their normal counterparts but the main difference is an added ability to their arsenal. It can be teleportation or even worse- they can fire guided missiles that hit for huge amounts of damage. (so keep moving)

The real fun starts when you find the teleporter and the boss spawns. It is when randomly spawning enemies start to continuously spawn around you for the next minute and a half, creating a horde aiding the Imp Overlord or whatever boss creature is randomly spawned.

You repeat this dance with the Devil until you beat the game or experience permadeath and have to start over.

I had some issues during these 16.6 hours of playing. Once I had no audio which was fixed by restarting my PC and once the game crashed on last boss fight. Also, game might slow down when there is too much going on on the screen. But I still love the game and I would recommend it to anyone who likes action platformers.

reviewText:
After crashing on a planet you're tasked with a simple set of objectives.
-Survive
-Find the teleporter
-Survive some more
-Eradicate everything
repeat.

For most games this could wear thin and become repetitive rather quickly but that simply isn't the case with this game.
When you first play, chances are you will die a bunch without really knowing what to do. You'll unlock something else though and it will get easier over time. Think of this as a survival/horde mode roguelike countra-ish shooter platformer that never gets stale.

Each play through will generally net you either a new power up or unique character class to eviscerate and dismember the various lifeforms of each planet and area. It has a Binding of Isaac feel in a sense that things are swapped and randomized with each play through but you'll always fight the same bosses and end boss/stage. Much like Isaac your power ups stack and you can have some really brutal and devastating combinations by the time you get to the end.

The different classes and characters you unlock all have different and interesting criteria to make them available for use and there is something satisfying in seeing that you have reached a new tier of badassery when you are now plowing through enemies with dual pickaxes or laying down your heavy shield and firing cover shots to keep the wave of enemies at bay.
the starting class Commando" is more than suited for the task at hand
recommended: but it should be known that every character plays completely different from the next and has a dedicated skill set and pool of abilities.\n\nThe bosses as well as the native creatures populating the planet are all aggressive and will swarm you the minute you come within proximity of them. This game also gives you a sense of urgency to complete the planet by steadily spiking the difficulty as the little ticker in the corner continues to count. If you can handle it you can play as long as you want
hoursPlayed:
you can even get all the way to end and start back from the first level with all of your power ups in hand. There is a flexible and open level of choice that allows for revisiting the game and trying different things time and time again.

Risk of Rain comes complete with a somewhat minimalist pixel art style and the characters would be moving dots if the view was pulled out any further but it also helps give the monsters a look of towering giants and puts you in David V Goliath scenario for the duration of your journey. All of this is backed by an amazing and atmospheric soundtrack that will constantly have you nodding your head or getting pumped in rhythm of the beat.

You can get as much as you want out of this game but if you put the time and effort into it
voteText: you can squeeze an amazing amount of time and play out of your 9.99. Overall I give this game an 8.8/10 and recommend it to anyone who is a fan of roguelikes

reviewText:
Risk of Rain is an action-platformer with roguelike elements, with some interesting mechanics wich I'll try to explain the best I can.

Even if you start with only one playable character, there're ten of them total, and each one plays differently, thanks to his own four attacks.
As time passes, difficulty will increase and enemies will spawn endlessly until you find the teleport, wich makes you fight for one last endurance round; beaten that, you can advance to the next level. Like other games of this genre, you can find active/passive upgrades (like piercing shots, increased defense, missiles and so on), but you can level-up too by collecting experience. An interesting fact is that powerups do stack, so you can have increased effects by collecting more of the same.
Once you've completed enough levels, you can choose between replaying them to gain more loot, or going to the final one; you can easily grind more powerups if you want to, but the game can be beaten in less than a hour in a good run.
Bear in mind that this is the kind of game where things get bad pretty fast, and you have to start all over again.
Pixelated graphics are really good, but sometimes the action on screen become a little too chaotic. Chaos apart, gameplay is overall pretty much solid and fun.
The game's soundtrack is AWESOOOOOME, I love it.
Also, this game has coop, playing with other people works well and in my opinion some classes are not meant to be played alone.

Reccomended if these features caught your attention, and/or if you have friends to play with.
I don't think Risk of Rain is a masterpiece, but it's a really solid game.

reviewText:
Roguelikes have exploded as a genre lately, largely due to the number of indie productions out there exploring interesting ways to take an absolutely classic title and bolt new mechanics to it. Games like FTL, Rogue Legacy and Paranautical Activity instantly come to mind, taking randomised areas, crazy power-ups and eternal death as a basis and building them into something new and fresh.

Risk of Rain takes the idea of an impossible Roguelike to new heights. The hook of this 2D action platformer is rather simple: it literally gets harder with each passing second. Immediately the player needs to make a conscious decision: do you grind out the game in the first few minutes when the enemies are few and far between, farming gold and unlocking passive abilities that will help you when you reach the ten minute mark and all hell breaks loose? Or perhaps you want to rush through as many stages as possible before the difficulty curve rises. Risk of Rain is all about risk and reward, and while it doesn't necessarily break genre conventions, it manages to provide a compelling twist on basic mechanics.

Players are given access to a number of characters, each with four unique abilities that will aid them in combat. Each of said abilities has a cool-down timer after use, so learning which character fits your play style, and how they fit in with the rest of your team is imperative for survival. In the beginning you only have access to the assault trooper, but after multiple runs you will slowly unlock a cast of devastating characters that will help you see the game through until the end.

Once you select a character it's game on. You are dropped on a hostile world, filled with enemies. Each enemy killed will net you some gold, which can be spent unlocking chests found in the level, or taking a gamble and spending some at a divine statue. Sometimes this will yield you amazing items, other times it will take your money and laugh at your tears as you received nothing at all. Each time you use one of the statues the cost goes up also, which often had me throwing money away at it three times before I realised I was broke.

There are tons of items throughout Risk of Rain that will give you the upper edge, most of them offering passive buffs against your foes. There are a select number of consumable items you will find along the way that can be used to get yourself out of a tight jam, and there are also some helpful assault and healing drones that you can spend money repairing so they will follow you around and help against the onslaught of enemies. Just like any Roguelike, learning how to use these items in unison is key to survival, and after a dozen or so runs, you will begin to understand how it all fits together.

Each level essentially has the same goal: find and activate the teleporter which will call in a randomised boss fight. The bosses are tough....really bloody tough, and they will definitely give you a run for your money. To make matters worse, the timer is still creeping up towards a harder difficulty, and regular enemies are still spawning into the world, which makes is a cluster of pain and misery. Once the boss has been defeated the enemies stop spawning, you are left to clear the last of them, and then you can teleport to the next level. Before you leave however, you better search for any chests you may have missed, because each time you teleport you will lose your gold.

Risk of Rain keeps you on the edge of your seat the entire time, simply because that ominous timer is always ticking in the upper right corner. Slowly but surely you see the difficulty status rise from easy to no chance in hell and the sweat starts forming on your brow. You want to make sure you survive the game, but you also need to do it as quickly as possible. It's an impossible task, one that is truly captivating and kept us coming back for more and more.

While Risk of Rain supports solo gamers, the true core of the game lies with the four-player co-op. When you're tackling the beasts of other worlds with three of your best friends, each playing a different character and you are all working in unison, the game really shines as something special. If you're not likely to play the game with friends, I'd almost recommend skipping it all together; that is how integral the multiplayer truly is.

Risk of Rain manages to pull off the pixel look with style and flair. The characters are enjoyable, the enemies are ghastly, and those tunes are fantastic. If you can swing a few dollars, definitely pickup the soundtrack from the website, it's right up there with Fez and Monaco in terms of great indie game albums.

Highly Recommended
Be sure to check out Nerd House Gaming for more reviews!

reviewText:
This
game
is
AMAZING.

The mechanics are well-oiled (especially after the last updates; now, it flows smoothly). The OST is simply beautiful. The graphics create a unique atmosphere: the gameworld is dark-toned but not lugubrious; you feel lonely, but never properly desperate, and the scenarios are always enjoyable (even after countless hours of replay). Also, the storyline of sorts is gradually revealed via item logs and monster logs you acquire after some time playing - the game starts  in media res. You don't need to know what's going on to enjoy it, but it surely adds to the flavor. I particularly like this form of storytelling: a very good game becomes more and more fascinating once you start realizing (well, perhaps not exactly) what's going on after some exploration. It reminds me of Diablo II in this point.

Most important, though, is that it is PURE FUN. Very challenging and very rewarding, it leaves me wanting more every time I play. Actually, I sort of developed an emotional attachment to this game; when I started playing it, I was somewhat distant from videogames (after 24 years of being a total videogame nerd), not really willing to play too much. reviewText:
The longer you stay on this hellhole of a planet, the tougher things will get.

But you're stranded. So. Please start moving.

The inherit challenge of Risk of Rain is to balance speed with thoroughness. Dwell any particular region longer and you're bound to discover (and be able to afford) an array of random weaponry which stacks together in clever ways, turning your hopeless vagrant into a prayed-for messiah. But there's that catch ... the longer you dwell in one zone, the more infernal the next will be. So as you fight simply to survive, you'll also be gauging time and charting hypothetical routes through the mysterious wasteland ... hoping to come across the right combination of moneys, chests and sacrificial totems in efficient order.

Aside from the planet's devious armory, your years on the frontier have supplied you with a certain set of skills. Regardless of your profession, these core skills usually take form in a weak-ish basic attack, a middling form of crowd control, some type of evasion, and a signature ability (think of this as the one that won you all that money on The Universe's Got Talent: Killing Edition). Each time you use a skill - beyond the basic attack - you'll have to wait a few seconds before you can use it again. As that one random monster crab is quickly joined by every casual acquiantance from his apparently quite-social life, those seconds can seem like an eternity. But you'll need to use those skills with abandon - conservation is for another time and place.

Again. Don't stop.

As your deaths accumulate, Risk of Rain becomes a game about learning the ins-and-outs of an alien frontier while constantly pushing yourself to discover new corners of its relentless universe.

Your only choice of profession at the start is a fine-tuned but vanilla-bean commando. But just as you begin to master your skills, you'll unlock a new, entirely unique character to possibly nudge your game progress further. Trust those who have come before: The new characters will often feel useless on the first playthrough. At some point, you'll wrap your brain around the death-delivering potential of each. And as you pour gallons of acid across shadowy plains or single-shot the entire health bar of one of the game's gargantuan bosses, you will learn to feel invincible ... for a minute or two at least.

Each of the planet's progressively elaborate environments includes a familiar basic layout from play to play, but its random generation makes each play just uncomfortable enough to force you to make decisions on the fly. Level talk is boring, but do note: the surprisingly elaborate final stage is reward in itself.

Risk of Rain is a game that requires skill and cunning ... but not so much skill and cunning to be abusive. It drops a torrent of challenges on you ... while giving you delightful ways to overcome them. To this survivor: It's earned a place in the Roguelike Temple of Elders.

Be sure to visit.

Just remember to keep moving.

reviewText:
Great fun and super addicting. Fast paced platformer and roguelike that makes you fight with increasing difficulty the longer you stand around. As you take longer to finish areas the difficulty increases adding more powerful enemies and upgraded bosses the longer it takes.

It has a very similar item system to Binding of Isaac, in which you must unlock items by completeing certain tasks before they are available in the game. While there aren't achievements for ALL of these, the game has a listing in the menu telling you what you must do to unlock them, and the item pages give a short description over the padlock as well to show you what you need to unlock certain items. Starting now with 100 items to unlock and use, I am hoping we get a major update similer to Wrath of the Lamb and I suspect we will!

The worlds are randomly generated as well, but I am not sure if this is infinite, or they have a finite nuber of designs at the moment. It is a 2D sidescroller instead of the overhead view of Isaac, but uses a lot of the same concepts.

The game also adds a bit of lore to it with unlockable monster profiles that give you a great background on them and some funny dialog. The items also all have their own item cards with interesting infor and funny comments about them.

You unlock several (10 total) new playable characters with completely different skills and abilities to play through the game giving it very nice replayability. While in Isaac you start with basic tears and small stat differences, each character in RoR has its own unique weapons and weapon abilities to start with regardless of what items you grab. The items enhance your character in many interesting and unique ways.

Graphical style is very simple and may seem offputting at first, but it works fine and the pixel art is perfectly good. Don't disregard the game based on this!

The only issue I had early was the default controls, which seemed to be designed for left handed players, but fortunately they ARE able to be rebinded to our preferneces and I did jsut that so I felt more comfortable.

This is the next great Indie roguelike that is highly addicting, and totally worth the buy. I highly recommend it to fans of Binding of Isaac!

The game has Achievements and trading cards. The Achievements I feel are a bit underwhelming, however and don't give the same sense of completion as the ones for Isaac did. Hopefully they will address this with further updates to offer more ideas and challenges with them. Not that it needs them to be a good game, but it expands the challenge having new ideas and challengs to achieve.

reviewText:
Can be turned into a hardcore Super Mario Brothers with enough headstompers and jetpacks
10/10 - Would Grind more Headstompers.

Okay, now seriously. This game is an 2D platformer shoot-'em-up with loads of Roguelike elements, and to tell the truth, it's an addictive hardcore game, and after over 100 hours, I still find myself enjoying this game (boy, what an year)

The hours of dying may get you mad sometimes (Damn you Jellyfish!), but that it is purpose. Once you get used to the difficulty, you will find yourself enjoying this game much more, and it doesn't get old. I think it is really worth your time. There is even a online coop mode, where you and your friend go all the way trying to beat the game (even with all the bugs), and with the artifacts, you can turn the game into your own challenge. It is really that good, just like The Binding of Isaac.

The game consist of you trying multiple times to reach a teleporter and advance to the next level, collecting items (usually randomly generated, if not for the use of one of the artifacts), which will eventually help you on your quest through out the game. The game also keeps you into it with unlockable characters and items, as well as the randomly generated levels. If lucky enough, you could turn into an rampaging god of death, killing every single enemy that come into your face, which I got to admit, it never gets old. The satisfaction of being so powerful and sort of unkillable just makes it more fun, and with a certain artifact which turns enemies into elite mobs only, it can turn into a very fun and hardcore challenge.

I deeply recommend the game, as it's controls are easy; the game itself is easy to play, but hard to beat; A very worth and thought soundtrack; a simplistic but yet enjoyable and nostalgic artwork; High replay value; A good game to play in your free time, or to spend a weekend trying to beat;

This is Risk of Rain, and welcome to your possible doom.

reviewText:
Ever seen a man get chased down by crabs and torn to limb from limb? I have. ♥♥♥♥'s horrifiying yo.
First thing to go it's the dude's sense of cool, he hits the ground running and starts to panic. When he realizes he isn't fast enough to escape on foot the second thing to go is his sense of gravity. He starts pounding the jump key like it was his lover in the doggy-style postion. When he runs out of room to jump he lets out a primal chimp scream and jumps headlong into a hoard of hungry crabs, guns blazing. Welcome to Risk of Rain, buddy.

The objective is simple. Find the teleporter on each level, flip the switch, hold the line until the timer counts to zero, then make like a tree and get the ♥♥♥♥ outta there. But there's a catch! If you decide you want to perform the ol' five knuckle shuffle just cause you've killed every enemy on the level you'd be making a grave mistake. This game gets harder with every minute that passes. Kind of like your uncle Jerry at your middle school play of Annie. If you die, that's it, no second chances. This isn't Super Mario, son. If you aren't on a full adrenaline-pumping-frenzy working your way through levels at redline speed you're next year's history lession. And that's the truth, Mac.

Lucky for you that you've got some help. You can find items hidden in chests around the levels that will help you clear the levels. These items aren't used the condoms you find around your local park, no baby these are Evil Dead 2 Ash's chainsaw arm levels of cool. You can also use the online multiplayer if you can figure it out with friends to fight through the hoards of monsters waiting for you. This turns out less like you and your commando squad of badasses tearing through everything like you were Rambo's children and more like that one scene from Aliens. You know the one.

You can get eaten as up to 12 different characters! That's a lot of flesh and metal for the monsters of the planet to sample so try to unlock them all!

reviewText:
Like the stages of meth:
1) the rush- you buy it on impulse and play
2) the high- the satisfaction that comes when you finally don't die in the first 20 minutes
3) the binge- the massive amount of runs that you've played over the course of 200 hours to get that satisfaction again
4) tweaking- once you reach the skill cap, game becomes easy and you play it out of habit
5) the crash- you realize that all your time is being eaten by a stupid indie game and that it's preventing you from playing other major releases, like a controlling spouse blocking out your friends
6) the hangover- you feel empty without it and thirst for it
7) withdrawl- the two weeks before you relapse, when you've tricked yourself into believeing that you overcame your addiction and value your dignity more than the game
8) relapse- go back to step 2

reviewText:
Punishing, but really enjoyable little rougelike with emphasis on fast paced action and easy to learn but difficult to master classes. Each class has it's own set of skills which will significantly change the way you play, but unfortunately only one (out of ten) is available from the start.
As with most rougelikes; levels, items and enemies are procedurally generated and permadeath is enabled but game never feels unfair, since every playthrough offers something new. Due to it's difficulty and random nature it will require speed, precision and adaptability. Luckily there are a lot of items spread out around the level that will provide passive and active bonuses like increased rate of fire or various status effects, as well as more interesting ones which I'm not going to spoil since discovering new item and monster log entries will be your main source of accomplishment in early stages of the game. However as you unlock more drops and get familiar with each class, things will get easier. This is the point where time becomes your biggest enemy (well...besides all the other big enemies). Game implements a timer in the upper right corner that will gradually increase difficulty as time passes, forcing you to find a balance between becoming more powerful and just getting to the next level with all your bits intact. It provides a nice compromise, keeping a challenging gameplay, but still providing the feeling of controling an unstopabble killing machine.

There are some problems on the technical side, like the occasional but gut-wrenching crash that will erase your progress and leave you sobbing, unresponsive controls in menus (especially if you're using gamepad) and problems with online co-op conectivity and Steam achievements. I would also be amiss not to mention brilliant sountrack and appealing pixel art.

All in all, in a sea of rougelikes this one manages to stand on it's own, providing responsive shooting mechanics, hordes of different enemies and items and a great balance between frustrating and adrenaline-pumping gameplay. A great value  for money.
voteText: 37 of 44 people (84%) found this review helpful 3 people found this review funny

reviewText:
Risk Of Rain is called the sidescrolling version of The Binding Of Isaac and it kinda is. But Risk Of Rain gives you multiple characters (all except one need to be unlocked first, however) and many skills to use, and more variety in its levels. And it can become quite challenging real fast. Enemies randomly spawn in the levels and you can use your skillset to take them down, earning you experience and gold. Unlock chests and buy items on your way to keep yourself from dying, because you *will* die. It's just a matter of time really. The items you find are randomly generated and are always useful. They have no negative effects (if they do it just depends on the total number of enemies walking around and the sort of level you are in). So the goal is to find as many as you can. Each level ends with a boss fight (or fights) which you, obviously, have to defeat. Once defeated you have to take out the remaining enemies before you can teleport to the next area. But, once you teleport you 'bank' your money, so you start from scratch again (your items will remain with you, of course). In the beginning you will probably last just several minutes, but once you unlock better items and characters these sessions will increase up to 45-60 minutes I guess.
I haven't mentioned it yet, but you probably were already aware of it, and that's the fact that if you die, you have to start completely over. I love it !

So, if you're into roguelikes give Risk Of Rain a try. It's definitely worth the risk.

[Rating: 82/100]

reviewText:
As one of my favorite games, Risk of Rain is highly recommended.

Most modern gamers will be confused by the graphic, but honestly if this game is built 2.5D in Cry Engine your game will crash so bad, my point: the gameplay is the most important part you should be looking at. Risk of Rain can be very addicted, everytime you start from the beginning with default data and you work your way to become a badass and with the new (kind of new) artifacts system, this game generate so much varieties that I can not count. Basically you chose one of the unique characters blaze through every stage and stock items, level up and build up your character and the objective is to beat the final stage.

One of the main features is the game's difficulty, it grows as the time pass. A decent gameplay management is required as the game can be tough to beat for a new player. RoR will keep surprising you with new contents (characters, items) that you will unlock, varieties tend to increase as you explore more. Which keep a well loop and create a high 'replayability'. RoR also contains several small secrets waiting for you to discover.

I have seen people complaining about the multiplayer experience, which was tough to me as well. Since the developers of RoR are independent developers, a server can be luxury indeed. Simply learn how to port forwarding will be enough to host. No hamachi required, I can prove it myself but who ever is hosting need a decent internet efficiency.

Despite lack of official server (some people actually host servers look it up), RoR is a pick up and play, rogue like action game, with very intriguing item and character design, and it is constantly updating. I can't illustrate how frustrated I feel when the game beat me and some ironic words pop out mocking my failure, or how awesome and satisfied it can be, when I beat the game with tons of items I collected. In other word RoR provide really nice difficulty options where things can get nasty require you to pay some attentions in order to beat it, or you can just sit back, relax, enjoy the show.

If you are available to play co-op, co-op is not too different from single player, which just add some additional chaos on your screen. The soundtrack in RoR is another feature to enjoy, musics in the background certainly polish the game into a another level it is simply astonishing and perfect. You can find all the little details proving that there are people (devs) who care about their games, and it is tons of fun when you are relaxing and reading some introductions of the item you've been using in the game, as well as the monster logs. Sometimes the game can crash if data overloaded (because it's the nature of the game), or some minority bugs happen to get in your way but overall RoR is a must-have game, and trust me you need to go deeper to witness the sorrow of the rain.

reviewText:
Highly addicting platfomer roguelike game !

The attention to smalest pixel details put into this game is awesome. You see from the animation of it especially the characters.

*Character Options
There are different options of character that you can play and unlock along with your progress in game. Different character has different style of owning the game.

*Looting
Loot is the main element in this game, as you progress you can unlock even more loot. More and more until you become a demi-god , or not at all and you will die is shame.
You die once and you start over from zero, while actualy you only need to finish 6 level ,which you will only be able to get through by dying over and over again until you can beat the game. And you can never have enough of it. Trust me.

*Atmosphere
The music is good . It suits well with the game experience and overall character. The atmosphere of foreign planet and the mood of playing space-alien like game.

*Dificulties
Another main aspect of this game is also that the dificulties will increase along with the time you play the game from the begining. So if you are not fast enough to gain level or loot, and the dificulties increase , be ready to have a really hard time.

*Co-op
The good thing from Co-op is that you can owned the game with your friends. As much friend as you can , but the cons is that you have to share the amount of loot you get and that means you have to share your strength that you usually get when you play SOLO (where you can greedily have your own loot). But anyway playing this game with friends is really addicting.

I am really hoping to see another sequel of this game if it were to be made . And i believe everybody will feel the same too.

reviewText:
Let me start off by saying that I've had amazing fun with this game and that it is nicely designed and loads of fun to play, but as of right now I won't recommend it.

When the game first came out it had its bugs and some framerate issues, nothing gamebreaking though. Recently though, the devs brought the game to a newer engine, and it caused LOADS of bugs and problems, even though the fps problems are mostly fixed now. I don't recommend it because even though it is loads of fun, the devs have abandoned it for the past weeks and haven't spoken to the community at all. It needs a big patch to fix the annoying bugs the game currently has and some balancing on some of the characters so that they become more viable and fun. I really like this game and I want it to thrive, but it raised more than 400% what it requested on kickstarter, and the developers NEED to address the problems it currently has, especially considering how much extra they raised.

If you're really interested in playing the game you should download the demo and try it out. If you really like it you can pick it up, the price is a steal for what the game offers anyway, but bear in mind that the current state of the game is very poor and the devs really need to put some work into fixing all the problems it currently has, and that's why my review will remain negative until the devs adress all that.

reviewText:
Risk of Rain could have been just another action rogue-like. What truly sets it apart is the inclusion of a time-based difficulty meter, which turns it into a rather intense survival game.

The goal of every level is as follows: look for a giant shiny red teleporter, then trigger it and survive waves of enemy spawns for a set amount of time (90 seconds on Normal mode). After the timer runs out, kill any remaining opponents and you can finally teleport to the next level. When you've completed five levels, you're given the option to teleport to the final stage or to revisit the previous ones.

This simple concept forces you to constanly find the right balance between rushing and exploring: you want to make the most of every level in terms of upgrades, but hang around for too long and the ever-increasing difficulty meter will make you pay. A typical playthrough can last an hour or more; and if you happen to die, no extra lives or continues: you're starting over.

The rogue-like elements are on point, with dozens of interesting items to discover and unlock as well as twelve character classes with very specific gameplay twists. Once unlocked, you can also choose to enable up to ten artifacts which alter the gameplay in a significant way. While not fully randomized, each stage has several different possible layouts which ensures every playthrough feels somewhat different.

A huge selling point for me was the option to play the game in local/online coop. Couch coop is great fun and quite playable, only requiring the players to stay relatively close to each other. Online coop gives the players more freedom and, for the most part, works very well; however, certain items (Chargefield) and possibly characters have a tendency to cause game-ending crashes.

This brings me to the flaws of Risk of Rain: a somewhat less polished technical side seems to be causing consistent problems for some users. Aside from very minor issues, it has been totally fine on my end (and the same goes for my friends), but I would definitely recommend testing the game as soon as you purchase it, and being ready to request a refund if you can't get it to work. A couple other nitpicks: the interface is rather bland and the platforming - not a huge part of the game, thankfully - can be infuriating.

On a more positive note again, the pixel art is quite decent, and the lore that unfolds through the monster and item logs paints a convincing universe. Last but not least, the soundtrack is amazing - whether you end up playing the game or not, you'll definitely want to check it out if you enjoy nice things.

tl;dr: a great blend of (hardcore) rogue-like and survival to enjoy on your own or with selected friends. Excellent replay value for the price.

reviewText:
I went into this game knowing absolutely nothing about it other than the name, the cover art, and that it was an RPG rougelike. I've now invested over twenty hours into it and after I finish this review I'm probably going to go play more.

Risk of Rain is addictive. That's the word I've found myself describing it most as. It hits the perfect sweetspot of challenge, luck, and skill. There's a visceral sense of empowerment- every time you collect a new upgrade, you actively feel stronger. All the visual effects that pop up coupled with seeing your inventory stack along the bottom creates this really unique sense of progression, as eventually- with a bit of luck- you can reach a point where absolutely everything you touch is obliterated in a miasma of fire, metal, and spirituality. The upgrades are all nice and varied, every single one having a unique effect such as adding a new type of damage or a chance to fire an additional projectile or a new way to heal yourself. It's not like other rougelikes such as Binding of Isaac where there are a lot of items that drastically change how you play- all of them just add effects and bonuses, making you into a walking powerhouse that just gets bigger and badder as time goes on.

A typical run will be about an hour if you're going for straight completion to several if you're like me and go back to replay the earlier levels and stack as much gear as possible. The game gets crazier and crazier as you level up, and if you make it that far I recommend trying it at least once. I also recommend playing with a controller- the keyboard controls work for the early levels, but once things pick up it's too cumbersome to recommend. The levels do get a bit bland, as the layouts are reused and the environments are pretty but don't make much difference. The soundtrack is solid and atmospheric, and the art direction is absolutely top-notch. The writing is worth note, too- the descriptions of the items and monster logs have a personality I wasn't expecting. I got excited every time I found something new because I couldn't wait to read up on its history. And any game where I can feel a serious, grave attatchment to a protagonist who just weaponized a ukulele can be called a literary success.

If you like RPGs, buy Risk of Rain. It's dirt cheap, and has that special feeling of leveling up in spades. All the characters are wildly different and change up the core strategy in really unique ways, and there's tons to discover and unlock. It's some of the most fun I've had with any video game lately and I'm absolutely smitten.

reviewText: Risk of rain is a simplistic yet intruiging indie game with a lot to it.\nIt's minimalist approach to a rogue-like is unique. Risk of Rain's seemingly simple exterior leaves you with a burning passion to explore every thing this piece has to offer. It's cruel, that's for sure, but this game is extremely fun, especially when you pace yourself and ensure that you're taking your time to get everything right. There's a number of playable characters, each offering their own way of playing this gem. Some of the unlocks, however, aren't the clearest on how it is to be done, leaving you with the shame of having to resort to the internet to find out what's next. Overall, Risk of Rain is an austere piece of somewhat savage software that'll lure you in with it's gorgeous art style and strike you with it's moderately high difficulty curve. For any fans of the rogue-like genre, this is a definate pick-up.

reviewText:
Let me just start by saying that this game is AWESOME

At it's heart, the game is an action platformer with a very old school feel.   There a few new school elements, the most obvious one being the item system.  If you have played Binding of Issac, this will be immediately familiar to you.  You acquire items that passively make your character more powerful throughout the game by using currency and defeating bosses.  This system is incredibly well done:  Almost all the items make an impact, yet there is nothing that feels overtly broken.  Even items that do not have an immediate, obvious application are revealed to be very powerful when paired with certain other item combinations or characters.

The genius of the game really reveals itself as you unlock new characters.  There a few that feel like they are there as a novelty, but outside of those one or two, they are very well made with distinctly different feel and strategies.  The characters function similarly to ARTS characters with different base stats and 4 distinct moves all mapped to a different button.  Once again, it was shocking to me how much the game changed when using different characters.  It seems strange to say, but I was not expecting that level of depth.

A lot of people will play the game for the carrot-on-a-stick nature of the unlocks, and the siren call of actually trying to beat the game.  Even after these tasks are accomplished, however, the game never really loses its appeal.  Having an amazing run and going through the entire game (which usually takes an hour or so) is just as satisfying the 10th time as it was the first.

When you start off, the notion of getting to the 3rd level can seem daunting, let alone beating the game.  The games learning curve can be somewhat steep, but when you come over the rise of competancy, you will really appreciate how robust the pacing, item system, characters and scaling difficulty of the game is.   Was an absolute joy ride from start to finish.

8.3/10

reviewText:
Risk of Rain is a strategical Indie arcade-style shooter in which the player endures a constantly increasing difficulty of enemy forces while gaining experience to level-up, purchasing items and upgrades, and searching for a teleporter device that forces the player to survive a boss fight. The game shares an intriguing element with other titles in that the further you go and the more time it takes to get there, the more progressively powerful the endless waves of enemies become.
Here are several reasons to give Risk of Rain a run while running for your life in-game:

Leveling System - What was originally a foreign element to me now retains some clarity. I will be honest, I did not notice the fact that characters had a level when I began my first trek into the Risk of Rain world, especially since I was so overly focused on surviving the merciless onslaught of consistently spawning hostiles. It was only after my first few playthroughs that I truly noticed the leveling system’s effect on the game’s entirety, as it acts simply as an in-game marker on how well that run’s character was sustaining, and even acted as a gauge for comparison to the play time to see how the player was progressing during that particular playthrough. This is not to say, however, that the leveling system is a useless ploy. When a character levels up, they receive bonuses to health and damage, which is definitely useful throughout the game. What I mean to say is that the leveling system is unique in that it is not something the player has to focus on, though it can sometimes signify that the player has to either spend more time in defeating enemy forces or has time to find the teleporter due to the amount of work they put in.

Character Selection - Each of the twelve characters in Risk of Rain has a completely unique playstyle to master. For instance, the Commando is a more tactful starting ally who is equipped with a pistol the deals medium damage and has a long range to which requires no cool-down for its use, a canon-like projectile weapon whose shots connect with multiple enemies within its line of fire, a basic combat roll which negates all damage within its arch, and a submachine gun burst that momentarily fires on both sides of the Commando player within a straight line. The Enforcer, however, is a close-range gunman equipped with a slow-firing short-range shotgun that has a slight knockback effect against enemies, a shield bash that is close-ranged and stuns all hostiles upon impact, a stance change in the form of a one-way shield block which increases fire rate for the given direction and redirects virtually all incoming enemy damage from the Enforcer’s front-however, the Enforcer cannot turn around whilst this mode is toggled-, and an explosive projectile launcher with a longer cool-down rate that has a decent knockback effect combined with explosive damage. There are eleven playable characters to unlock-with the Commando present from the game’s start-, but each requires a considerable amount of time to acquire, and even more time to master.

Time-Based Increasing of Difficulty - As previously described, Risk of Rain utilizes a time-based difficulty system as well as the “Easy, Medium, and Hard” modes you would find within other titles. What sets this approach apart from the usual is that it completely and consistently influences the way you play. It is suggested that the player act quickly by locating the teleporter device upon spawning, but this requires said player to evade enemy forces persistently, subsequently causing them to be weaker when the end-stage boss fight does occur; on the other hand, because the enemies become increasingly difficult over time, grinding and exploration is somewhat limited to a shorter duration. This chaotic paradox raises a call to action within the player, in which the fast-paced gameplay is heightened to the condition that critical decisions must be made promptly. This system heavily drives gameplay, and this has been a favorite approach to gaming for me as well as a worthy mental and emotional adversary.

Collectible Drops and In-Game Achievements - After countless deaths, the player should feel as though some sort of progression has been made, and the collectables found through each world achieves this satisfaction. A percentage of this progression comprises not only of how far one proceeds through each run but also of which upgrades the participating player unlocks during the playthrough. These, as well as collectible ‘Monster Logs,’ can be viewed in a catalogue from the main menu of the game. The in-game achievements create a sense of progression as well, and even allows the player to unlock additional items such as upgrades and additional characters by completing certain goals.

TL:DR - Risk of Rain is one of those games that can be a chaotic mess and still retain its charm, which for some games is inaccessible. It is one of those games that you play as if it were embedded within an arcade cabinet and you have infinite quarters, without fear of failing. It is one of those games you just play: do not degrade yourself for not defeating an end-of-world boss because of a single mistake, do not worry about being a completionist while driving yourself mad just because an item did not drop when you needed it to. Risk of Rain is one of those games that deserves its claim as an Indie Gem, and that one should just play to play. Thanks for reading.

reviewText:
Risk of Rain is a rogue-like that offers a few interesting twists on the genre, but utlimately this game doesn't give the player a compelling reason to keep going back into the rain-stained void.  I'm going to keep this short and just discuss the two main design errors that kept me from enjoying this game.

The first strike against this game is that it has a very skewed difficulty skewing.  As time progresses in Risk of Rain, the enemies grow in numbers and strength.  The early portion of this timer makes for an exciting experience that forces the player to formulate a careful balance between farming and progressing through the initial levels.  If the scaling maintained this logical, linear progression, Risk of Rain would be brilliant.  The problem is that near the end of the timer enemy statistics are hyper-inflated to the point where the game becomes slow, dull, and almost impossible to survive.  No matter how lucky or unlucky one is in their item drops, eventually they will reach a point where progress is slowed to a crawl due to insanely inflated HP pools and huge damage numbers.  Here's the critical reason why this is so bad: Risk of Rain is a game about kiting.  You must be able to whittle the horde as you kite across sections of each map, and when you can't effectively kill anything after multiple loops, things go badly.  Difficulty can be punishing yet rewarding, or it can be merely punitive.  Risk of Rain's difficulty starts as the former but quickly morphs into the latter.  Either the enemies need to be slowed in their evolution, or the player needs better scaling ratios.

The other problem with the game is that a large portion of the character kits are badly designed for the engine in which they inhabit. Risk of Rain is a game mostly about kiting, but only a few of the characters' kits are actually able to do this with any efficacy.  The varying roster brings a welcome diversity to the game, but any initial excitement about new characters quickly begins to fade once the player begins to realize that only about three characters are actually worth playing when attempting more difficult and longer runs.  The developers seemed to have forgotten that the game requires constant kiting, and as a result you'll find throughout character diversity many kits that inhibit or restrict one's ability to kite, and the damage compensation for the restricted movement isn't nearly enough to make it worth the sacrifice.  The Huntress is an example of a character that is designed with the game's core mechanics in mind.  Her speed, fast cooldowns, and movement are unparalleled, and playing this character augments all of the postive aspects of the game.  Kiting the flood of enemies is a rush and most mistakes can be assigned to player error. The Bandit is an example of a poorly designed character -- weak mobility, long cooldowns, and no true edge in damage.  The Bandit either would need more movement or much higher damage ratios to be a character that is worthwhile.  Perhaps many would argue that they enjoy this hieratic approach to character rosters -- and some might even enjoy the extra challenge of a poorly designed character -- but I would have liked to seen multiple playstyles designed around the mobility required in Risk of Rain.

There's a few other problems with the game, but those are the two main things that kept me from going back to it.  The initial struggle of balancing farming v. progression was addicting and compelling, but this experience was quickly ruined by an atrociously designed end-game.  The thrill of unlocking characters, too, was diminished once one understood that only three have well designed kits. It's an interesting game that will be exciting for a few hours, but if you've played other Rogue-likes, you'll soon see the design errors that hold it back from true greatness.

reviewText:
Risk of Rain? Pfft, more like Risk of PAIN. Because, you know, you'll die a lot in the game.
Actually, it's not as much of a risk as it is a certainty. Hold on, let me try again.

*ahem*

Risk of Rain? Pfft, more like Certainty of Pain. Wait, no, that's crap. Hm, synonyms of certainty...inevitability...destiny? Destiny of Pain? That sure sounds dark, though. Although I guess it fits with the game...where was I going with this again?

Dammit, okay, so Risk of Rain is about an interplanetary cargo ship that gets attacked by aliens over a deserted planet. The ship crashes, and you, playing as one of about a dozen different classes, have to, with the help of the cargo you find scattered across the planet, defend yourself against the native creatures and find your way back to the ship. It's a 2D jumpey-shootey platformer that is kind of sort of roguelike-ish; the areas you go to are more or less random, with the locations of the teleporters and items - and the items themselves - being fully randomized, but each area has only a couple of variations. This is not a bad thing - once you play through an area enough times, it's easy to figure out the general layout, meaning that it's potentially easier to find the teleporter to the next area. This saves time, and in Destiny of Pa Risk of Rain, time is not on your side.

The longer you spend in the game, the harder the game gets. More enemies spawn more rapidly, the enemies become stronger and tougher, and at higher difficulties, boss enemies can spawn in the middle of a level, instead of only at the end. This not only keeps the game's difficulty up, but it also forces you as a player to keep moving forward. Do you farm enemies and search for items, or head straight for the teleporter to prevent the difficulty from rising any higher than it needs to?

The game also features both local and online co-op, which is great, but sadly both methods have their own problems. Getting online co-op to work requires more than passing knowledge of computers, and local has every player sharing one screen, which makes exploration difficult. When it works, though, it can be a blast - exploration and monster-killing become much easier with multiple people, and working in a team allows the more specialized classes, such as Sniper and Enforcer, to shine.

Risk of Rain has good controls (the game is perfectly playable with either a keyboard or a gamepad), plenty of things to unlock and discover, and a punishing difficulty level that keeps it from getting boring but is never discouraging. Even though you start with one basic (albeit well-rounded) class, the Commando, getting the other classes offers a nice challenge on top of the gameplay itself, and each class plays very differently from the rest. The game is a ton of fun and you should buy it.

reviewText:
I had been meaning to write this review for a long time now, but I couldn’t stop playing this game long enough to do it. Roguelikes and roguelike elements have been trending lately, and that’s not necessarily a bad thing. Risk of Rain houses a great challenge and addictive gameplay.

Risk of Rain requires skill, reflexes, and luck to beat. Every character feels very distinct and they are all fun to play. Each character has four skills, three of which have cool downs, which you have to manage in order to survive. Damage comes in percents and the numbers get high.  Along with number crunching, the randomized items are an essential part of the game. These stackable items provide a number of bonuses, passive and active, that make survival possible.

It is hard to describe what makes this game so intense and rewarding.  Difficulty increases as time goes on, so it becomes a tradeoff between risk and reward. Fully exploring a level could result in multiple boss spawns and death by elite level creatures, but rushing through the levels could leave you underpowered and lacking items. Your main objective is to find the teleporter in each level, but its location is randomized each time. Your starting point, chest placement, bosses, items, and overall location are all randomized as well. The intensity of the game never lets up because of the increasing difficulty, and it will take the right items and movements to beat the game. However, every playthrough feels like it’s teaching you something different: you will start to learn the layout of levels, the quickest routes, the main teleporter locations, and so on.

If learning isn’t reward enough there are also plenty of unlockables. Besides the nine characters that need to be unlocked, there are a ton of items as well. These are all unlocked in a variety of ways that can make for some interesting challenges on top of the base game. Playing by yourself is great, but this is also a great local or online co-op experience, because teamwork is essential.

Outside of the base game there are some logs and statistics to look through. While the item log seems to be less serious, the monster log provides some neat insight into the monsters of the game. The statistics page on the other hand, provides interesting insight into yourself and how much of problem this game has made out of your free time.

Risk of Rain is hard to put down. The art and music are both really great, and the game feels solid and rewarding.

reviewText:
Risk of Rain. What a game. At first I was skepticle to try this game out being that I assumed it was just your average MOBA with some sort of twist to it like most games are nowadays. What you get is a lost soul stranded on a mysterious planet fighting for survival against a army of creatures that want nothing but your death. This game is intense, sweaty hands intense. You play as one out of eight character who's only like, 10 pixels tall against giant monsters that absolutely tower you while trying to fight off a horde of smaller monsters as well. You really do feel a sort of pressure on you while you play when you remember that the monsters only get stronger as time goes on, so you're left with the decision to scour the level for items or to just continue on before you become overpowered. This game is hard, it does not forgive and death will force you to start over, and I wouldn't have it any other way. This is a game for the skillful and the strong, anyone who can't face a good challenge will not survive long in this planet.
I love the game. Since the game randomly generates the level to be different every time, you're contantly left guessing where the teleporter is. The wide assortment of items to attain is amazing as they all have different effects that help you in your survival, such as mushrooms that provide speedy healing or a rocket laucher that fires a barrage of missiles at your enemies. There are just so many possibilties that it you're constantly left playing the game over and over again because it's impossible to get the same playthrough twice. That leads me to another thing I love about the game, it's infinately replayable. Since there are so many items and characters you can unlock, it gets to be addicting as more of the game's content becomes avaliable.
The Multiplayer mode is a complete blast. You would think that with teamwork, the game should be a breeze, but no. The more people are together at once, the more monsters come to rip you down. It's so much fun to combine you are your friend's unique abilities (assuming they all play different characters) and to coordinate together to survive as effectivly as possible. I always thought it was hilarious how sometimes your friends would get so desperate for items that they dive for every possible chest. Multiplayer adds a new layer of challenge as you now have decide to distrubute the random items evenly, or to have one man become the strongest and carry the rest of the team to survival.

Now it's time for the bad.
While it's fun and absolutely crazy when you're trying to fight off the hordes of them, after the big masses are dead, you're left with a few stragglers hidden somewhere in some corner of the map which becomes a chore to hunt them all down. One complaint I have with the game is how luck based it is, which I suspect isn't unreasonable considering the nature of the game, it's frustrating to spend your limited resources on a chest only to get some item that wouldn't help at all. There is very little incentive to use the shrines as they have such a high chance for failure, I would only use them if I had excess money on my way to the teleporter. Multiplayer is a pain in the ♥♥♥ to set up. This game uses the system where you have to connect to a friend via IP address. This system is very outdated and has only been nothing but a pain to get working. I cannot open my ports if my life depended on it which leaves me utterly unable to host games, leaving me to depends on my friends to play multiplayer, it becomes quite an inconveience to type in IP addresses for every person. At the very least, there should be an option to copy paste.

Aside from those issues, this is an absolutely terrific game that deserves to be played at least once. It offers so much for the moddest price of $10. It's a real bargan to get so much play time from this game. Get it now!

reviewText:
This game is always fun to play no matter what you are doing. Supposed to be studying for a test? Play Risk of Rain. In class? Play Risk of Rain. At a funeral? Play risk of rain.

In all seriousness, Risk of Rain or RoR is a 2D side-scrolling rouge-like game where you fight unlimited and countless enemies to uprgrade and customize your character to survive the crazy world. There are multiple different classes of characters with unique abilities that set them apart from eachother. The world is always different through every play through of the game so it never gets old.

There are random chests placed throughout the world that you open with money earned from killing enemies that give you upgrades or items that help you survive. The twist is once you die you die forever. You have to see how long you can manage to live and possibly beat the game if you are good enough but the game is VERY challenging.

There are also acheivments and leaderboards in game and on steam that help you keep track of how good or terrible you are at the game.

The game also offers an online co-op mode that you can play with up to four friends to help against the harsh enemies and worlds you explore.

Conclusion: RoR is a rouge like adventure game that never gets old and is very addicting to the point were it can ruin your life.

I would buy this game at full price so if it is on sale it is definitely a steal.

reviewText: Currently it is the best game I have played yet. I have seen many other games of this genre, yet this trumps them all in my personal opinion. The playability of this game is great: 4 player local, 50+ players online.. if your computer can handle such a large amount of players. The game is chaotically fun for the whole group. It wont get boring because of the fact that you can increase the difficulty level as the time increases. If it's too hard though, try to unlock artifacts that may make the game easier or harder, try combinations of artifacts. I have bought about 4 copies of this game for my friends to play with me, and I highly recommend this game to anyone willing to try it out.\n

reviewText: The risks are high in Risk of Rain, where the risk of danger and the imminent risk of dangerous alien life increases the risk of survival. reviewText:
+ Fun, yet very, very challenging game
+ Difficulty steadily increases the longer you play
+ Very simple goals and keybindings
+ Total of 10 playable classes, 9 of which need to be unlocked; adds variety to the game
+ Lots of interesting power-ups and consumables that can be found and purchases in-game
+ Lots of collectibles that can be later viewed from the main menu
+ Optional co-op increases replayability

- Gameplay gets repetitive quickly if this type of game isn't usually your 'cup-of-tea' (it isn't mine)
- Boss battles can be inordinately difficult, often simply by throwing more mosh-pit crowds of enemies at you
- Had nothing but headaches trying to enable controller support (I've tried everything, and read through pages and pages of forum posts and FAQs; nothing works and it seems to be a very common and widespread problem)

reviewText:
A gem that, although not under-rated, is definitely under-recognized. A platformer with simple mechanics, but hours of fun and a constant sense of urgency, as the longer the game progresses, the harder it gets.

It works wonders as a time-waster, as it provides fantastic solo and co-op play. There's a sense of progression, as you constantly unlock new characters, new items, entries, find secrets dancing aliens at the very last level was the coolest one I've found yet!, and loads more.

Honestly, if you enjoy platforms with simple but difficult to master gameplay, stop reading this review immediately and purchase this ♥♥♥♥. It's top-tier.

9/10

reviewText:
Risk of Rain is a roguelike action-platformer...I guess? Really I can't keep up with all these crazy genres/sub-genres anymore. Mainly the game works like this:

1. You crash land on a planet filled with hostile alien life-forms.
2. You must seek out the teleporter.
3. You have to survive for 90-120 seconds while killing these aliens and the stage boss.
4. You acquire items that unlock additional abilities.
5. You can either escape the planet or continue searching for items to become a God of alien-destruction.
6. You never get a normal night's sleep again.
7. You You You You You You You You You You

Honestly I'm not sure why I enjoyed this game as much as I did. I'm usually not a fan of roguelikes. While I understand and appreciate the work that goes into designing a game in this style, it just seems like 80% of indie titles are some variance of get stronger...but don't die or you'll lose everything!" Risk of Rain however

reviewText: Risk of Rain is a level-based, rogue-like platformer that is several large boats full of action-packed fun. You land on an alien planet, perform diplomacy incredibly poorly by shooting everything you see until it explodes into the planet's currency, buy random loot, kill bosses and move on. Each runthrough is nicely randomized based on the loot you pick up and the character you select, and each character is well rounded with a MOBA-style 3 moves and 1 ultimate ability to help you get sh*t done. Platforming handles beautifully, all non-tank characters have movement abilities to make traversing the desolate environments flow nicely and last but not least, playing with friends is fantastic.\n\nYes, It's a good game, 10/10 would reccomend, but it isn't perfect. The main issue I have with risk of rain is the time limit. Let me elaborate by saying that RoR doesnt really have a time limit; it simply gets harder for every 5 minutes of playtime. but a game would be boring if it didnt get harder as you progress" I hear you bleat. Of course difficulty curve is important
date: but RoR literally gets harder the LONGER you play
recommended: rather than the further you get. You are rewarded for finishing the level as fast as you possibly can

I don't enjoy feeling rushed when I sit down to play a game.\n\nThe only other major issue with RoR is that some enemies take WAY too much firepower to bring down. reviewText: I previously didn't like this game that much, mostly because it ran at a glorious 5fps and it took over an hour to finish a single stage. The recent patch has made the game run at constant 60fps, even on my terrible dualcore/integrated graphics laptop. Completely loving the experience now that I can properly play it. Also, holy crap is it ever difficult now that the game is no longer played in super slow motion.\n\nIf you're looking for a game to put pressure on you, challenge you, but do it in a controlled and fair way, that you can replay endlessly, Risk of Rain is a sure thing. Especially if you also dig games like The Binding of Isaac and are looking for something more heavy on the action.

reviewText:
Risk of Rain is a somewhat Roguelike platformer. The game consists of five stages. Each stage is selected at random from a choice of ten to fifteen maps per stage, with the maps being variants on two or three actual landscapes. For example, for the first level, you will find yourself either in the Ancient Forest or in the Dried Lake, and each one of those has several variants.

Throughout the game, enemies spawn and attack you, the type of which are determined by the map you're on, and the number of which are determined by how far the game timer has progressed. It starts at Very Easy, Easy, Medium, and Hard, and eventually progresses to I SEE YOU, I'M COMING FOR YOU, and HAHAHA.

At around HAHAHA, you might start having two or three boss monsters spawning with the normal enemies at random.

As if this isn't bad enough, you're pretty fragile and horribly, horribly outmatched by the unending waves of enemies you face. Your weapons are laughably weak in comparison to your foes' attacks, and the fact that there are Elites and Phantasms which ramp the power up to even more ludicrous heights only makes the game more inherently unfair.

You kill enemies to collect currency and experience. Experience gains you levels, with the usual make everything better" that comes with levelling. Coins can be used to unlock treasure chests or sacrificed at shrines.

The items you gather will make your life a little easier. Not much. Sometimes
date: negligibly so. But enough negligible boosts can really stack up after a while.\n\nThis game follows the Goldeneye model of achievements. Each achievement you earn comes with an in-game unlock - some will unlock items that will be able to drop from thereon out
hoursPlayed: like the specialized and challenging Sniper
voteText: or the adorably toxic Acrid.\n\nAll in all
helpfulPercent: I have ground my face against this game for hours and hours
votesHelpful: have only won a handful of times
votesTotal: and have loved nearly every minute. This is not for the Facebook Games generation
votesFunny: this is for the motherfudgers who thought Contra was a good time
commentsCount: even if they never could get anywhere without the Konami Code."

reviewText: This game, besides from having neat pixel graphics, is one of the most fun and challenging games you can find around here. And multiplayer is cool as well, making it more fun and challenging.\nTo summarize the game, you have different characters to choose from, each one with four different skills; you have collectibles that give you different active and passive attributes and finally you have hundreds of monsters to kill, really hard enemies, and a timer which increases the amount of difficulty the longer you play.

reviewText: Let's start out by saying that this was my first ever Roguelike. I had never played a Roguelike, but really wanted to get into the genre, and found this gem. The game altogether is amazingly fun. Starting out with a small arsenal of toons, you can choose and develop your playstyle very early on. Over time, new characters can be unlocked and used, in turn releasing new items to be unlocked through use of said characters. A unique achievement system leads to an innovative way of implementing completion to the game, as when an achievement is completed, a new item is unlocked to be discovered in game. The randomized item discovery and unique unlock system make for an overall great and lengthy experience, and I would highly reccomend this game to any and all who enjoy a fun, quality game.

reviewText:
Risk of Rain is damn hard, you will die a lot in it, and these deaths will be unfair. It will require every ounce of attention, time management skills, and luck. The difficulty ramps up over 40 minutes, and after that the game is laughing in your face, throwing everything it has at you like Freddy Krueger doing his one joke stand-up comedy routine, and his one joke is having you drown in a vat of snakes and bugs.

But the reason for my recommendation is at the point of the game where you're so buffed that no monster, big or small, can touch you. The part where kills gain you extra maximum hit points, and you're taking out four of these ♥♥♥♥ers every few seconds or so. The part where you have so many drones you're raining bullets into faces and watching them all go down, firing frantically while the horde is held back by your absolute, undeniable firepower, being showered in gold, health, and experience, knowing that you cannot be stopped and that their absolute best is going to have a hell of time killing you.

And then you get ganked by some horrible little ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ you didn't see in time to deal with.

If you're not that much into Roguelike-type stuff, maybe skip this and come back to it later on. If you're looking for a co-op game, it requires port forwarding and is not as much fun as doing it alone. Other than that, it's glorious and frustrating and compelling.
