reviewText:
Risk of Rain is an indie platformer with a strong focus on fighting against large mobs of enemies, and some rouge-like elements such as unlockable characters and items. It's unique characteristic is that difficulty isn't tied with level progression, as the game allways becomes harder and harder as the clock ticks away.

Art, soundtrack, hard difficulty and different playstyles for different characters are it's strong points. Perhaps you will enjoy being swarmed and being forced into kiting tactics rather than brute force or skill upgrades (there aren't any), perhaps not.

Despite not being story-rich, the world is memorable, the soundtrack is one of the better ones (and one of my favourites), and the pace and progression is spot on for my tastes.

The game is highly recommended if you're on the fence. If you dislike platrofmers or rage easily, probably avoid. Looking at the game on Twitch and YouTube, it's not easy to see what's so good about it. I had a *very* poor opinion about it, until i was convinced to try it. Immediately, my opinion went from utter dislike to surprised enjoyment.

You kinda have to love games where you gotta move fast and react to chaotic swarms of enemies and projectiles rather than stalk things quietly and plan ahead (for most characters anyway, Sniper does it sligthly differently). If you enjoy very difficult, breakneck speed gameplay then this will satisfy you thoroughly. The game is very easy to play and very hard to beat. Beating it feels tremendously satisfying.

The style, soundtrack and overall mood is somber rather than guts n' gore or slapstick. Like a weeping willow with a minigun, things get very violent but rather than being a hero or villian you're forced to fight as hard as you can just to survive.

The story is largely ambiguous, told in bits and pieces of journal entries or item logs. Whatever the reasons brought you there, it's going to end in a lot of death.

Items are numerous, humorous and range between very mildly useful and overpowered. With items and command artifacts it's possible to tweak gameplay difficulty and make the game nigh-on-impossible to beat. If you're into that sort of thing.

The main gimmick of increasing difficulty as time goes by is executed very well and it's possible to win either by taking your sweet time and hoping to acquire as many useful doodads as possible or by rushing as fast as possible in order to clear later stages before the difficulty increases. It will make the first few attempts pretty hard but the game stays challenging longer that way. And as i've mentioned before, beating the game is an acomplishment!

I've also mentioned the soundtrack being excellent but i'll mention it again!

There's some bugs. The game engine was upgraded post release and as a results some old bugs were fixed and some new ones appeared. The level generation can occasionaly bug out and co-op play can suffer from port-forwarding problems or disconnects. Other bugs are pretty rare and minor but they get patched out occasionally.

As a single player game Risk of Rain is almost a classic. As for multiplayer, well it's got a few problems and it's difficult to get it working until the bugs get fixed.
voteText: 6 of 7 people (86%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Risk of Rain is an addicting action-based platformer with a healthy dose of challenge. Solo or Co-op, the game is a blast because the game gets progressively harder as you play it! With the idea of collecting power-ups and perks in a struggle to get more powerful and balance out the constant rise in difficulty, you and your friends will find yourselves getting constantly bombarded with more and more enemies and bosses until you die or beat the final stage.

It has great replayability due to the multiple characters to unlock (each with their own very unique playstyles!) and the ever-growing random buffs and perks you unlock by doing challenges! It also features fluid pixel art and great soundtrack to boot. Gameplay is smooth and easy to pick up, but has a decent amount of depth in terms of timing your skills right.

If you like the sound of any of that, I definitley recommend Risk of Rain :)

reviewText:
Risk Of Rain is a brilliant platformer/rouge-lite, the main thing with this game that pulls me into this game is how easily I can switch from being under-powered to over-powered and then back again in split seconds. (mostly from getting too cocky when I have certain power-ups. :P) It's genuinely a hard game and I love it for that reason. The music is a selling point as well, sort of a rocky/electronic/ambient thing.

The difficulty scales just right for me, it gives me a good 2-5 minutes to do what i need to do in each level, so I can do either a quick pick-up-and-play run or i could do a good 40 min run to (rarely) get to the last level. Plus this game actually makes me want to collect every single power-up and monster log just for the little storys you get alone.

The only gripe I have with it is how complicated it is to connect with friends, when I want to connect with a friend I have to use a program called Evolve[evolvehq.com] that gives me and my friends a temp IP address, and even that fails some of the time.

All in all, this is a solid game that rates highly on my games list.

reviewText:
It's hard to judge a platformer with only 10 levels to offer, usually one would say that it is lacking in content. However, when you factor in the 16 possible combinations of the first 4 levels, the myriad of variations each level has, and how item drops are completely random that gives passive buffs to the player, plus the inclusion of 9 unlockable classes and 1 default class.. You have this roguelike platformer where no 2 play throughs are the same.

The gameplay is really fantastic, lending itself to real frantic action with tons of tough enemies and impossible bosses. It has a unique mechanic of cranking the difficulty up as time passes, and so it becomes a wild race against time to get as many items as possible in as little time as possible to keep you alive. There are over 100 items to pick up with more than a handful of them being deployable during the game for added effects.

It's not just the gameplay that is great, the 2-D spritework and the forlorn-sounding music complete the experience of playing this game. It looks great, it plays great, there is a lot of depth and challenge to be had. I would say that this is one of the best Rogue-likes to come out in 2013. Go pick it up.
voteText: 7 of 9 people (78%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
A fast-paced and unforgiving 2D platformer-shooter with 8-bit, pixel graphics.

The storyline is rather thin, but solid enough to relay to the player who you are and what you're doing. A stranded pilot on an alien planet and trying to not die, respectively.

The gameplay starts off nice and easy, but gradually picks up the pace, ramping up the difficulty exponentially. Apart from 2D platforming and shooting things, this game can very well be categorized as a rogue-like. With permanent death, unforgiving difficulty and a lot of randomized items to aid you in combat, fans of rogue-likes and fast-paced action alike will appreciate Risk of Rain.

There are 10 classes to be unlocked, each with 4 distinct and unique abilites. The variety allows for an amazing amount of play styles and strategies. Combined with the at times randomness of items and shrines to waste your money on, players will need to hone their skills and rely on luck as well, if they are to escape this hostile and indomitable planet.

reviewText:
I would recommend this game for the upgrade system alone. There are around a hundred items which are randomized, the interesting part being that they all work with each other and can stack with each other. This means that every playthrough, your style of fighting and main source of damage will change dramatically.

One time you'll be rapid-firing a machine gun which has a chance of doing double damage, inflicting bleeding and fires faster the lower health you have - the next you'll be staying at a distance, firing the same machine gun on the same character but with mortars and rockets being launched at the same time, causing enemies to combust and leave pools of fire on the floor.

The huge combination of items as well as the unlockables and large variety of characters and playstyles mean that not only is this game fun, but has a hell of a load of replay value. The main downsides for me are the lack in truly randomized levels (the layout itself stays the same, but the loot locations change) and the lag at later levels.

A definite recommendation nonetheless, and a great game.

reviewText:
So my friends bought this game a couple of weeks ago and I decided to buy it too. I asked them if it was a good idea or not. They said, that it wasn't, but I didn't believe, so I bought it anyway.

Gameplay:

The game is full of action and things to do. From killing stuff, to completing in-game achievements to unlock new items/characters.

Game itself smells like The Binding of Isaac with it's repetitive ways and unlockables. That's probably the part that really hooked me up to this game.

Music:

The other thing I liked about this game is music. Daaamn it's so good. I could listen to it all day, all night.

Graphics:

The graphics of this game are old school retro, not really anything fascinating, but I can't imagine it in any different way.

P.S. It's really hard, even on very easy mode.

PROS:

+Repetitive
+Alot of unlockables
+AWESOME MUSIC
+Different characters to play as

I can't think of any negative stuff about this game other than that you have to have an open port or use Hamachi (or other programs) to play co-op with your friends.

reviewText: Risk of Rain could stand a little more optimizing, but for a game made in Gamemaker of all things it's surprising how engaging it is. The art style is consistent and manages to look great even when your character could be rendered on a digital watch. Combat is fast, constant, and feels good, character progression is a constant motivation, and the soundtrack is top tier. The multiplayer is absolute ♥♥♥♥, a total ordeal to set up which I assume is a limitation of the engine, and unfortunately I haven't been able to get it working. Despite that, Risk of Rain is closer to the traditional rogue-like with randomly-arranged stages, distinct character classes and randomized loot from a very large pool of options than most games professing to be rogue-likes" on steam today."

reviewText:
This game does what it wants to do properly well. It has it's flaws, but all in all, it's well executed and presents challenging gameplay with great difficulty balancing from easy to hard.

The game does NOT handle well internet lag. It's supposed to be synchronized between the players, but with pings of around 300 ms, monsters started desyncing and, due to that, completing stages was only doable by the host, as I could not kill 'all enemies on screen'.

The content that the game offers is worth it's price, but I would have definitely paid more money if it offered double the content. It's got 100 items and 7 classes so far, which isn't bad, but gets a little repetitive after a few hours. The key to making the game fresh is, instead, placed on the many classes you can unlock and play with. The soundtrack offers great tunes that motivate the players to keep going. It's very cinematic and complements the scenery in a really classy and well done way.

Needless to say, this is much better enjoyed with friends, as all class combos offer great variety in strategies. The game's difficulty is much better adjusted for teamed up players, as different classes complement each other against certain monsters.

No need to mention that this game is really hard. REALLY hard. Beating this on Hard difficulty is not a feat for the faint of heart.

6/10

reviewText:
A lonely atmosphere. A struggle to survive. A breathtaking soundtrack.
These are things to expect from Risk of Rain. I personally haven't experienced all there is in the game, but I've put enough time into it to confidently say that this game is something special, something we need to see more of.
The story is found throughout the world and through the items you find. Nothing's completely concrete, and the speculation can be fun. At least, I find it fun.
As a roguelike, you're punished on death, forced to start anew every time. The different classes and randomized map rotation, as well as some variables per map, allow the game to never quite be the same with each run through.
The music, though? Glorious. That's my special word for special things. This game touched all the right notes for the soundtrack and has launched itself into my top favorites. And that's tough.
The gameplay itself is hectic and fun as hell. Each class can handle each situation differently, although some can do so better than others. I personally like to use the Sniper. It's all about finding the right class for you.
Overall, the game was done very well with just the right amount of everything a game needs. Platformers your thing? Roguelikes your masochistic desire? What the ♥♥♥♥ are you waiting for?

reviewText:
A fun and challenging 2D sidescrolling rogue-like in which you can get a demi-god adrenaline rush by stuffing many powerful artifacts down your space trousers and making hundreds of dudes face the wrath of your explosive fury. Start as one dude, unlock many other dudes with varying abilities by doing certain things, like beating the game, etc.

The difficulty of the game slowly increases as time goes on, so you and probably at least one other friend should split up, and balance between murdering space dudes, getting their exp, gold, items, collecting items from chests by spending money you've collected (because videogame), and finding the teleporter in a timely manner which initiates a gauntlet for about 90 seconds and spawns a boss which you must then destroy. After the gauntlet is over and the remaining enemies are dead, any player can use the teleporter to proceed to the next level.

Rinse and repeat several times until you get to the final level, and kill the final boss who wants you and your comrades incredibly dead.

In short:

> Explore, shoot things, collect items, find teleporter
> Hold out, shoot more things, enter teleporter
> Repeat, reach final level, beat snot out of final dude, probably unlock more dudes
> Repeat
> Go mad with POWER!!!!!!!

reviewText: Insanely addictive platformer with a lot of rogue-like mechanics. Even though the graphics does look bland at the first sight, the game mechanics are flawless. Replayability is extremely high (local and online co-op included): there's a lot of unlockables, such as new boosts, new playable characters (possibly, a lot more than that, but I'm just getting started playing the game). reviewText:
Brilliantly-made roguelike platformer from the guys behind Starbound. While superficially similar to games like Binding of Isaac or other action roguelikes, there's really nothing that FEELS like Risk of Rain out there.

The essentials: you are a survivor from the crash-landing of the UES Contact Light, which was hauling extremely questionable cargo when it was downed over an incredibly hostile alien planet. Play as one of eight different classes, pillage the wreckage that rained down from the sky as the ship crashed, and try your hardest to survive long enough to reach the Contact Light and get off the planet. This is a shallow summary, of course.

The basic gameplay is an action platformer reminiscent of Bionic Commando, but there's no grappling hook shenanigans: instead, every class has a completely different style of play, with four abilities. Every class has one basic attack, one crowd control power, one ability that improves mobility, and one very powerful attack that leaves them somewhat vulnerable but is tactically crucial. These range from the basic Commando, who is a classical sidescroller Dude With Gun What Shoots Mans, to stuff like HAN-D, a hulking janitor bot who punches things and launches drones to attack and heal himself, to the Bandit, a space cowboy assassin with a lever-action rifle and dynamite, to even weirder and kookier options. Every class is completely unique compared to every other class, and there's a ton of variety to be found for any kind of playstyle you like.

Beyond your class, you've got one slot for an active item and a functionally unlimited number of slots for passive items that improve your abilities or stats in some way. If you've played Binding of Isaac, you basically know how this works. Where a lot of the fun comes in is the sheer variety of items you can find and the way they interact with your character, as well as the intriguing and funny backstories behind each item, displayed in the game's Item Log, which is presented as the shipping manifest of the Contact Light. As you collect items, you'll eventually build a picture of exactly what the Contact Light was up to. The game similarly features monster logs for stuff you kill, which are random pickups.

Difficulty in the game is complex; while the game has three difficulty settings(Drizzle, Rainstorm, and Monsoon), it isn't immediately obvious what these do. What they primarily affect is the game's scaling difficulty, which is based on your in-game timer. As the difficulty meter ramps up, enemies get progressively tougher, more aggressive, and more numerous; at the max end, it can even spawn bosses as regular enemies.

In each level, you're looking for a teleporter which will take you to the next stage; activating it summons a boss, and once you've killed it and all remaining enemies in the stage, you can progress. You can either beeline for the teleporter straight off, or stay around for a while and try to slaughter enemies to earn money and experience with which to buy items and become stronger, but waiting TOO long becomes a risky gamble due to the ever-increasing difficulty. Too fast, and you'll be underpowered; too slow, and your foes will be insurmountable. Skilled play thus becomes a balancing act between progression and increasing your capabilities.

The game is simple to pick up and learn, but is staggeringly replayable, and this is helped by the beautiful aesthetic and wonderful music. For ten bucks, you are getting a LOT of game, and it's certainly worth your time to stand out in the rain for a while.

reviewText: Risk of Rain is a platformer/sidescroller/survival game that puts you in control of one of a few survivors of a crashed spaceship. You will have to fight enemies and earn money to purchase upgrades and progress to the upper levels. The game's difficulty scales with the time, adding an incentive for players to use their time efficiently. In each individual run" - or single playthrough - there are six levels
date:
each with harder monsters and more expensive upgrades. Boss monsters appear at the end of a level or sometimes in the middle of a level if the difficulty is high enough. Risk of Rain will require several playthroughs to fully explore what all of the upgrades do and how to play each of the survivors.

Read more for an in-depth look at Risk of Rain.

This game's story is largely told in the beginning and end cutscenes
recommended: as well as in monster logs - information about enemies that randomly drop when you defeat one. Some of the descriptions in the item log also hint to background story events.\n\nRisk of Rain [ROR] is a 2D pixelated platformer game. The art is excellent and each of the characters and enemies are unique. Each of the survivors has 4 unique abilities that are fairly balanced. Each one has their own forte and shortcomings
hoursPlayed: so experiment a little with all of them to figure out which one suits you. You only start with one character unlocked (the Commando)
voteText: so you'll have to unlock the rest.\n\nItems/upgrades are found in chests which unlock for a price. Monsters drop money and experience when killed
helpfulPercent: and both can also be found in small amounts within canisters. There are four ranks of upgrades - white (common)
votesHelpful: green (uncommon)
votesTotal: red (rare) and orange (use item). The first three ranks are items that are either passive or triggered by events
votesFunny: while the fourth are items activated by the player. All use items and skills (except for the primary basic skill) have cooldowns. There is also an artifact hidden within each level. Artifacts do nothing in the run they are acquired in
commentsCount: but after that playthrough a new artifact's effect can be chosen in the character selection screen. Each one adds a different game element (only elites spawn
column16: 500% damage but 10% health
column17: etc).\n\nROR also has an incredible soundtrack
column18: merging genres from electronic to trance to ambient to rock. Each level has its own exclusive background music
column19: giving it a unique atmosphere. The sound effects are very believable and yet are alien enough to convince you that the planet you are on cannot be Earth.\n\nRisk of Rain is an incredible platformer with solid gameplay mechanics
column20: excellent replay value and an addicting arcade-style structure. Online multiplayer is also available. A solid game all-around. Definitely worth purchasing if you enjoy a good thrill."

reviewText:
First i just wanna make clear, that this game has nothing to do with rain.

This is, the best Rogue-like game I've ever played, the goal is to get items as fast as possible, hurry to the teleporter if you think you can beat the boss, you've got like 2.5-5 minutes if you dont want to get your ♥♥♥ owned in the next level, so you better hurry! It's basically the same in level 2, 3, and 4, but at the end of level 4, when you've beat the boss, it will ask if you want to start over with all your items, or continue to the final level. If you beat the final boss, you beat the game. It's MUCH harder than it sounds like, and Co-op is recommended for survival.

Well I've beat the game, nothing to do here...  NO! This game has a great replayability, you can unlock new characters, items, achievements, beat highscores, and enjoy all the randomly chosen maps, each with unique background music. ALSO this game is made by CHUCKLEFISH, they make GREAT bagground music, and great games, AND THEY EVEN MADE STARBOUND! Worth 4 times the money if you ask me.

reviewText:
Against all previous statements and assumed beliefs this game is in fact neither a weather application or a simple game. It is actually a time machine, but due to chucklefish dropping development on all their games half-way through it can only send you forward in time. It acheives this by making you perform simple tasks, killing enemies and making your character survive as long as possible, but in reality you are coordinating the complex controls of this machine, quickling sending you anywhere from thirty minutes to well over an hour in one sit down. I found myself playing right after breakfest only to realize shortly afterwards that it was the next morning. Use this game with caution or else you will find yourself losing all grasp on time.

reviewText:
This game is a fresh take on the rougelike genre.  This game is great to pick up and play for a while with no real commitment.

The more you play this game, the more in game powerups you will unlock, which will give the game more depth.  The game has a random element to powerups, so some runs you will get destroyed, and others you will simply dominate.  There are also a handful of unlockable playable characters, each with their own unique play styles.

I love games I can just pick up and play, and this game is great for that.  It gets tough at times, but for the most part you will be destroying wave after wave of enemies, which is very satisfying.  If you are looking for something more than an hour here or there, this might not be your game.

For ten bucks, I say its well worth it.

reviewText: This game is challenging at first, but once you get through the learning curve, you can easily breeze through the game if you are playing a class you know well.\nThe multiplayer is simple and painless, and makes the game simultaneously easier and harder. Having two or more people obviously means that you have extra firepower, but you have to share money, exp, and items, providing a difficult balancing act.\nI would highly reccommend this game to anyone who is a fan of difficult games like They Bleed Pixels or Dark Souls, along with anyone who likes action platformers like Cave Story.

reviewText:
This really might be the most addicting game I have ever played. If you're on the fence about purchasing Risk Of Rain, let your $10 do the deciding and GET THIS GAME RIGHT NOW.

- This actually somehow makes it more enjoyable.
- The only thing more awesome than playing this game is playing this game with friends.

reviewText:
Risk of Rain is a very challenging pixelated game with RPG elements for a fast paced gameplay for you and your friends featuring a whole lot of unlockables, items and characters. When playing for the first time, even the easiest difficulty feels like a big hit. Great and forwardening soundtrack that always keeps you on your toes. High replayability in combination with great difficulty and items to unlock that won't let your fingers off the game for a good amount of time.

Though, after the first finished gameplay you realize it could use a view more levels to lengthen the game. For the current price the game does not really satisfy in regard of content.
The game is not optimized well in terms of performance and visualization on the screen. When things are getting too cluttered, a low- to mid-end PC often hangs on a view strings and slows down to a unplayable state. The final level always lagged on my older notebook, regardless of hosted or being the host and the monsters on the screen.
A huge let-down is the handling of lag when playing in multiplayer. The game often ended up being unplayble as the player with a high ping did not synchronize with the host, not being able to teleport to the next level.

All in all I would recommend Risk of Rain when it is on sale, otherwise it feels like it is missing content and polishing.

reviewText: Risk of Rain is a sci-fi platforming roguelike where you pick a character and run through levels while collecting a massive selection of (stackable) items to make yourself stronger and more likely to survive long enough to find a way home. The catch is that the more time you spend alive, the more numerous and difficult the enemies become, so there is a trade-off between mining levels for items and speedrunning. Any fan of Spelunky will appreciate its extraplanetary equivalent, but there are a few less-than-desirable traits which should be of note.\n\nUnlike Spelunky, Risk of Rain has a diverse set of classes from whom to choose. However, I believe they could be placed on a bit more equal footing. Where many games of all kinds, from TF2 to The Binding of Isaac, make sure that different classes are well balanced, Risk of Rain has certain characters which are clearly far worse than the others (no matter what one's individual strategy may be). Contrary to the achievement name, you will find the Robot Janitor, and you will regret it. Classes like the Enforcer or the Robot Janitor are simply too slow to stand any chance against mid-game swarms of enemies. They are, indeed, powerful classes, but the level difficulty ramps up too quickly to avoid the swarms (whether you choose to search for items or speedjogataleisurelypace). If you do not quickly find several of the same very specific items, you will die more frustrated than entertained. The other weaker" classes have some method of teleporting or defense-rolling to safety
date: but there is no health pool large enough to save you from enemies too numerous to kill and too fast for you to run away. That said
recommended: playing as the other classes yields a roguelike challenge with items and enemies worth the time and money.\n\nOverall
hoursPlayed: Risk of Rain is a good game with uniquely designed aesthetics and gameplay mechanics. This sci-fi roguelike poses a challenge which
voteText: though sometimes frustrating
helpfulPercent: still maintains considerable replay value.\n8.5/10"
votesHelpful: September 21, 2014
votesTotal: true

reviewText:
This game is difficult in the beginning. I am not going to lie. It will kick your ♥♥♥ down into the ground, then rub your face in the dirt. It will make you want to scream in frustration, having really good items, then dying for some stupid reason. It will make you want to quit. But I implore you, please do not quit, all those bad runs are made up when you get some of the few that beat the game. Then it's like all the other failures never existed. No amount of deaths afterword can get you off the high you achieve from beating this game.

Unlocking characters? Even better. You know that after you die on that run, you can play as a whole new person with new abilities. It's truly the best feeling.

Don't even get me started on the multiplayer, just goofing off with friends is hours of entertainment. I highly recommend this game. It will beat your ♥♥♥... but lovingly. It wants you to get better. And you will.

reviewText:
Risk of Rain will quickly eat up hours of your life, it's one of those games that are fun to go back to when you're a bit bored and not sure what you want to do.

I don't think anyone would regret buying Risk of Rain as it's a very accessible game that is easy to pick up and play for awhile, extra fun if playing with friends.

Worth mentioning however is that the game is far more enjoyable with a controller and the menus and such are a bit wonky. The game is very poorly optimized and while this will rarely be an issue many people have problem with halved (30 instead of 60) framerate on the last level, which means the game runs at half speed (not just half framerate, one second in the game will last for two second in real life).

Let me explain in a short list.
-Fun gameplay with fluid controls
-Collectable items for replayability
-An outstanding soundtrack
-Enjoyable level design
-A constant challenge even on easy, but not too much of a challenge, as the game gets harder as you get better.

All in all, Get this game. I see no real flaw with it.

reviewText:
Risk of Rain is an amazing 2-D platforming game. The story is about a guy destroying a ship and killing everyone but the Commando. reviewText:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8B8gjurmPoc&list=UU7_-PLIhjsEBwIQXqKxmNpA

Risk of Rain is a roguelike with some minor platforming elements, and
an option for playing in co-op mode.  The game comes with difficulty levels that
offer a wide variety of challenge in gameplay, as well as artifacts that can
unlock more difficulty options.

You play as a character stranded on a planet, trying to escape by
reaching the teleporter, then stay alive during the 90 seconds it takes to
teleport to safety.  The more time you take to survery your area, the harder
the game gets.  Surviving in the game comes down to a combination of luck and
using passive abilities strategically.  That being said, the longer you take,
the harder the enemy gets, to the point where the quantity of passive abilities
will make no difference.

This is not a game for those who have never tried roguelikes before;  rather
if you are looking for a challenge, this will entertain you, and even humble you
as you go through the game.  This game respects your time, and I
enjoyed playing it.
I have no problem recommending it.

This is a summary of my review video, which I encourage you to
watch if you are looking for a more in-depth review.

Thanks for your viewership and support; for more videos check click here.

http://www.youtube.com/user/SocioPyscho

reviewText:
Warning, Sliiiight Spoilers.

Risk of Rain?
This is an amazing game, extremely worthy of purchase.
When you first play, you are offered one character, the Commando. He has four skills, like you would see in a game like DoTA 2 or Awesomenauts.
So you play as the Commando, die a few times, kill some bosses.
Then, right as you think you get bored, bam.
You reach the third level, and unlock a new character.
Or you kill 3 bosses and unlock the Enforcer.
Or maybe you even beat the game and unlock the Sniper.
Then it gets really, really fun. You start exploring different characters, unlocking more items, and completing challenges.
Bring a friend along locally, and the fun just gets funner. Play online, and the same happens.
I have not gotten tired of this game after 24 hours. That doesn't happen often with me. 60% of games that have straight,  forward objectives get boring for me after a while.
So really, all in all, Hopoo has done an amazing job.
(Plus, Hopoo said PvP might be a thing in the future, so that makes it better.)


TL;DR:

The more you play, the funner it gets.

11/10.

reviewerDisplayName: i l l b l e e d
reviewText: Risk of Rain is a game in which you truly feel adversity with every step you take. It's an incredibly difficult game, but that tends to come with the rogue-like territory. The characters all feel fun to play as, and it's always incredibly satisfying picking up yet another new upgrade to add onto your already extensive pile of upgrades. This is a game that I've lost so many hours on, and not a single minute feels wasted. It can be very frustrating at times, but it's all worth it when you finally become a virtually invincible godslayer, ripping even the most terrifying monsters to shreds.
voteText: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Risk of Rain is a game you will try and fail in. Then try again and get a little further. Then try once more and get not quite as far as the first. There's a lot of elements to this game that are random. The biggest of which is the item drops. The quality of the items, the rarity and quantity are randomly generated. That not only makes Risk of Rain feel random, but also makes it challenging. For some reason I'll get further and last longer with worse items. Makes me think I'm on my game! The randomness can feel frustrating or unfair at times, but it adds major replayability.

There are a lot of pros and cons, but just know... Risk of Rain is a fantastic game. There are different characters you play as and unlock. You also unlock droppable items through achievements and tasks. The characters all play incredibly different. I believe there's 10 different options. In the game you'll spend the majority of your time dodging and platforming - trying to trick the AI into not being able to get to you. The difficulty also ramps up for every 5 minutes you play (up to 60mins). So ideally you'll clear the level, get all the items and kill the boss all in one sweep. That's usually not the case, since you have to kill enemies to gain money to unlock a chest.

A major flaw I've seen is the multiplayer. It has huge potential for a fun multiplayer experience but they missed it just a bit. You can play with 4 players in one screen. That screen does not get split. You must travel CLOSELY with your companions. I'm uncertain if online multiplayer allows you to split off. That's not the flaw, however. The upgrades are how you get more powerful. Only one person can pick up the upgrade, and upgrades are not shared. So you can either choose to split the upgrades between you and your buddy/ies and all be weaker, or have one person pick up every upgrade and have the others feel useless. This can also add some tactical measures to the game as well. If you know the upgrades well enough, you can give the ideal upgrades to the different classes and maybe be stronger as a unit then you would be with one godinator and 3 scrubby nubbies.

I'm tempted to say this game is ALMOST too challenging, but it wouldn't feel like an accomplishment if it were easy to make it to the end, now would it? I've played maybe 30-40 runs and completed once or twice. Damn it felt good when I beat it.

Play this game. Beat it with every class. Be my hero.

reviewText:
My friend bought a four-pack for around $7 for some of his friends, and I was gifted it. I highly recommend doing that, since the multiplayer aspect is great, but it does require you hosting and using your public IP address.

Risk of Rain is a rogue-like side-scrolling shooter (originally released in 2013) where you can choose from multiple characters (which act like classes) for different play-styles that will run great on any computer.* It is a perma-death game, but like most rogue-likes there are some things that you are able to save certain things. I have spent 40 hours on this game, and by now I can tell you that I had a great time throughout all of my runs. You also come across chests which cost money to open, and give you an item. These items spruce up the gameplay a LOT, and add a ton of super fun things your character does. There are three difficulties you can choose from before starting a game (in order of easy to hard): Drizzle, Rainstorm, and Monsoon. There are also artifacts you can find in the game that can add gameplay boosts, such as having enemies drop bombs that can harm you whenever they die, and having you be able to choose your item when a chest drops one.

The gameplay consists of killing lots of enemies until you find the teleporter which is in random areas around the map. Once you find the teleporter, the boss will spawn and you have 90 seconds until you can teleport away (teleporting away requires you to kill every enemy on the map). Once you kill everything and activate the teleporter, you are whisked away to another location. This continues for five more levels until on the sixth level, you are on UES Contact Light, which is where the final boss Providence is located. Once you beat that boss, you beat the game, but don’t worry, there’s a ton of replay value.

One of the best aspects that I’m very grateful Hoopo Games added is the ability for you to host a Multiplayer game and play with your friends. There aren’t any servers hosted by anyone else (as far as I know), so you have to host your own server, which includes you port-forwarding and using your PUBLIC IP address. Luckily, all my friends know each other personally and are fine with sharing IP addresses. We have a ton of fun playing this together.

Pros:
-Multiplayer support
-Cheap
-High replay value
-Good controller support
-Great gameplay
-Fun things to spruce up the gameplay

Cons:
-Confusing story (at least for me), but it’s the gameplay that matters for me on this game.
-Having to use public IP address for servers (not a problem for me yet).
-Crashes occasionally (about 5 times in my 40 hours of gameplay, not too bad).

I rate this game 10/10, because there aren’t a lot of devastating cons and it met all my needs for a great game, even in 2016.

Side note: I've almost played this more than I've played Fallout 4...

reviewText: Do you like this Neo-Roguelike Renaissance? Do you like platforming shooters? Do you like Item Stacks? Do you like dying (a lot)? Do you remember arcade games like Quartet and Rolling Thunder? How about games like R-Type, Gradius, and Nemesis? How about games like Robotron, Smash TV, and Sinistar? reviewText:
Really drags you in once you try it. I couldn't help myself and just went on playing with the purpose to reach 100% achievements, however stopped at 97% with few monster logs missing. It has an enormous replay value, which sadly ends once you unlock some artifacts (Kin, Glass, Command, Sacrifice) and items (infusion, chargefield generator).

Once you get them, starting on a lemurian map, grabbing early infusion and stacking on barbed wire soon makes you and unstoppable ball of death and after 30 minutes of farming you always beat monsoon regardless of the character choice.
That kinda killed the fun for me, as I couldn't just go back to the regular style of playing after trying that. All in all though, the point where you can possibly roll through the maps every time you play start after you've played for some 20 hours or so already (if you are fresh new to the game), probably less if you've played it before or read the wikis a lot.

Before that I still had lots of fun, trying to survive, which is not always that simple. If you play it the regular way, your every gameplay will be different, some items will make cleaning the levels a breeze, while other sets will push you to change your strategy in order to prevent your painful death. The graphics might be a little archaic, but I think it synergizes well with the game overall and it actually looks pretty neat. The background music is prefect as for a space survival game, it fits well with the atmosphere of being on another planet, alone. Another great thing about the game are the monster logs, which I found very well written and enjoyable to collect and read.

RoR doesn't escape few minor bugs like item containers (the always come in three and you can buy only one item) sometimes spawn all in the same place, so you can't even really see what you might get or some items not working properly sometimes (looking at you Imp Overlord's tentacle), but it's nothing gamebreaking. For me, the most annoying issue was the FPS rate in later stages of the game, I mean, I don't really have a gaming rig (yet), but for a game that doesn't involve any too complex graphics, I think it should run smoother rather than lowering my details to the minimum and the FPS rate dropping to 20-30 (which also affects the clock, so the in-game time is not the same a real life time).

Still, for such a low price, this game is well-worth buying. It costs like 3 euro, when there's a discount running, which is a funny price for the fun I've had, especially with the AAA games having 5-10 hours of gameplay with no replay value at the cost of 40 euros. I recommend it to everyone who likes games with roguelike elements and is a completionist freak like me.

reviewText:
Probably one of the most fun pixel games that has come out in an indeterminable amount of time.

Do you want fun? Risk of Rain
Do you want to feel overpowered? Risk of Rain
Do you want to feel overpowered with your friends? Risk of Rain
Do you want to have a blast playing through a game that far exceeds the standards of a two-man developer team.

Risk.
Of.
Rain.

If there's one thing that's not a risk about this game, it's paying for it.

reviewText:
If every Rouge-like could be as great as Chance of Precipitation, i'd love the genre to death.

Careful going outside folks, we've got a slight Risk of Rain going on. Make sure you've got your umbrella and in case you happen to be on a cargo ship that gets destroyed and you crash land on an alien planet, don't forget to bring a ukulele and an alien head to help combat the aliens that may try to murder you.

Chance of Precipitation is a 2D platformer that gets mad at you for being in the shower for too long. As time goes on, the difficulty rises until a transparent shadow emerges from the steam with a pot on it's head, challenging you.  actual enemy  .it creates a fun sense of urgency to quickly find the teleporter to the next level and efficiently deal with every enemy so you can proceed, but not so quickly that you barely have any money for the bus fare. It uses an item system somewhat similar to Binding of Isaac: you find and collect stackable passives and can carry one usable item with a cooldown. They do not however, affect your physical appearance (with the exception of one.)

one of the things I really love about this game is that despite how terrible your RNG may be, your items (with a few exceptions) do not directly affect your actual damage, which increases as you level up, so your deaths will 80% of the time be your fault.

The one thing there is for me to really complain about is the characters. a good chunk of them are very interesting and cool, but you'll be spending a lot of the game kiting enemies as you'll usually die pretty quickly otherwise. As such, it makes the Huntress definitively the best as she is the only one who'll automatically target enemies near her for all of her skills. Melee characters also tend to have a very hard time because of this, despite being probably the most fun to use. While the game is still very enjoyable, it is a bit of a crucial design flaw for a game like this.

in short, Chance of Precipitation is a girlfriend who is absolutely terrible to you but is way too cool to not hang around. You may be a masochist. Congratulations.

reviewText: A solid (and nicely priced) game, Risk of Rain is fun and the perfect introduction for newbies into the genre of games with roguelike elements. It's easy to jump into, controls are simple, lots of hidden unlockables for replayability, and the gameplay is straightforward. The straightforward gameplay has its pro's and con's. Personally, I think that it limits the game somewhat, because it does seem more repetitive than say, Binding of Isaac or Spelunky. The randomized levels don't make much of an impact here than it does in Spelunky. And the loose-nature of RPG-styled combat makes battles less intense compared to Binding of Isaac. But the lack of complexity, IMO, is what makes multiplayer possible and enjoyable. Now... if only there was matchmaking for the online.

reviewText:
I wanna write a legit review for this game, cause 90% of my reviews are troll ones that somehow get people offended. (via comment war) OTHERWISE let's get into it.

This game is difficult. know that and know it well, You're gonna die a lot. So if you get frustrated easily...glhf.
Risk of rain is a 2d shooter which has some of my favorite kinds of things, Items with effects that help you ♥♥♥♥ ♥♥♥♥ up
yes, that's right. ♥♥♥♥. ♥♥♥♥. up. Not only that the game gets super fun when collecting more and STACKING these items, so let's say you stack x3 with a item that makes you go fast, guess what? you're apparently the ♥♥♥♥ing flash now. (<- good)

Like the binding of Isaac it gets difficult the further you go, however in this game, it's way different. There are three main difficulties you can pick, Drizzle, Rainstorm, and Monsoon. (wow rain!) This is the base difficulty, I'd recommend Drizzle if you're new just to get the mechanics of characters down really.
But difficulty does not stop there. You're difficulty INCREASES by the amount of time you spend, so don't go pickin flowers son. It can get to the point where the difficulty bar literally laughs at you. ♥♥♥♥in demonic ♥♥♥♥.

You start with the Commando, first character and a personal favorite of mine. From there you start unlocking more characters, I'm not gonna list them all cause there's guides to  tell you all about the characters and shiz like that.

So now comes the question, SHOULD you buy it? Is it worth your money? Yes. If you like challenge, this is one hell of a challenge. or if you like 2d shooters, go for it.

oh and multiplayer is wonky at times soo keep that in mind. otherwise tl:dr - fun shooter that is difficult.

reviewText:
Perhaps one of the best 10$ games out there.

I sincerely recommend you to buy this game.

Now here's my reasoning on the games contents.

Music 10/10
Nicely orchestrated music, you can see that Chris Christofensenchris (sorry do not know the last name but it has a lot of Chris in it) actually worked to provide music to fit each level, and often moments too. Very relaxing while you're blasting away on the enemies that come.

Story 10/10

It provides discoverable items that the specific mobs drop, that give you more intell on them (Including a background story) not to mention that the games main story is simplistic yet fitting perfectly.

Gameplay 10/10
Now here's the fun, you collect coins by killing enemies, theres plenty of rewards in the form of chests, statues and more spread over each level, finding the chests, collecting the loot, getting more powerful as your enemies get more powerful each level, and each 5? minutes you spent in game.

This balances out perfectly the random odds of the items you gain. You can find use" items that are very powerful
date: and go on cooldown after each use. Not to mention that all the power-up's (Besides use items) stack
recommended: so getting a bonus twice is nothing less than still a great reward (as the bonus will be enhanced.)\n\nI've picked up many games for this amount of money
hoursPlayed: plenty even over. This is just pixelated greatness and 10$ is WAY below the actual worth in fun you'll have if this is your type of game.\n\nYou can play it Co-op to upto 4 players

reviewText:
Woot! Having a ton of fun with this game so far. It's fast, frantic and completely chaotic at times. Since the game's difficulty scales with time spent versus character level, it forces you to keep up your pace or risk falling beneath the power level of the monsters. One of my only complaints for this game is it can become difficult to tell what's happening when particularly large groups of monsters (or groups of particularly large monsters!) and attack animations are going off.

Definately the sort of game that you can play in a half-hour stint, or a four hour binge. There is a large variety of meta-game unlockables (including new items to find in-game and new classes) that keeps you wanting one more round.

Co-op is tons of fun as well! Local works perfectly, and while I ran into a few (mostly minor graphical) issues with the online co-op it was still incredibly fun and didn't detract much from the experience. Recommend!
8.5/10
Pros:
-Multiple difficulty settings for rookies to vets
-Unique unlockable character classes
-Crisp, fast-paced action
-Play alone! Play split-screen with friends beside you! Play online with friends everywhere!
-Cool soundtrack/art style... + explosions


Cons
-Minor issues with online co-op
-Action can become obscured by... the action
voteText: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
★★★★★★★★☆☆

Really fun rogue-like platformer. It's a difficult game to begin with, but as with games like this, the more you play it the better you become. There's a diverse range of enemies, bosses and unlockable characters to play, but the pick-ups recieved aren't all that different as they mostly modify a property of your health or damage. It's not all that noticable, but certainly is something to consider.

The levels aren't randomly generated, but the locations of objects within the level are. At first it seemed like this would get tiresome, but it allows you to become familiar with each map layout, exploting different points with different characters.

Pros:  Fun yet difficult, lots of bosses, classes and enemies, randomly generated objects on the map.
Cons: Somewhat similar pick-ups when looked at as a whole.

8/10.
voteText: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
+ Good pixel graphics with a great style.
+ Probably the best video game soundtrack I've listened to in a while.
+ Fun and engaging gameplay.
+ Very high replay value.
+ A wide variety of items and classes.
+ Challenging.
+ A great co-op experience...

- ...however, lagging can cause game-breaking glitches and sessions with more than 2 or 3 players usually result in a failure due to a lack of items. It's possible, but it requires actual co-operation and luck.
- A little too RNG-based. Started out with bad items? Tough luck, you're going to die.
- Framerate drops occur late into the game and slow everything down. (although this somewhat helps)

Risk of Rain probably is my favorite roguelike game. It takes a little while to get into, but it's very fun once you get the hang of it. It's also one of the few games which I purchased at their full price and I can definitely say it was totally worth it.

8.5/10

reviewText: I really like this game for some reason. It's not that amazing, but it's humble, and pretty fun with some friends. It can be a pain to set up the multiplayer mode, but it's fun when you get it to work and you start trying to make up team dynamics.\nSome classes are harder to unlock than others, some are just outright better than others. Some items you pick up are ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t, and others make you a demigod, but you'd come to expect that from a rouge-like-like.\nFor a dev team of two dudes plus a musician, it's darn good, and worth it if you grab it on sale.

reviewText:
What we have here is a platformer with procedural elements, a gorgeous pixelly aesthetic, an absolutely amazing soundtrack, and addictive, challenging gameplay. There are ten different heroes to play and they all have a unique skillset of four abilities. As a consequence, they all have a different playstyle, sometimes -dramatically- different.
Combine this with a hundred different powerups to collect which appear at random and a small amount of variability in the level progression and stage layouts and you've got a hard as nails game that's never exactly the same twice.
A single playthrough is a mere six stages, but even after you reach the point where you can win reliably, there's still challenge to be had, with an extra hard Monsoon difficulty mode and a new game plus option that lets you skip the final stage and replay the game over and over, retaining your character but facing off against larger and larger hordes of tougher and tougher foes.
Few gaming experiences I've had are as satisfying as starting out weak and fragile, but overcoming overwhelming odds to achieve nearly godlike levels of power. With enough items, you may find yourself able to stand uncaring in the middle of hordes of monsters, leap abitrarily high into the sky, or unleash piercing, explosive attacks that knock groups of enemies clean off the screen.
This game is addictive, challenging, and extremely replayable, and I highly recommend it.

与大部分roguelike游戏类似，打怪或开宝箱所获得的道具，遇到的BOSS，都有着很高的随机性。玩这类游戏，不光操作要好，脸也很重要，否则Game Over。


虽然没有中文，但是并没有什么大碍，英文看不懂可以下一些图鉴。

配合基友食用风味更加！
不过联机有时候也会遇到麻烦 ：延迟高、路由器需要配置环境。

唯一的不足：关卡不是随机生成，玩来玩去就那么固定的几个。

>///<良心的是，游戏依旧还在更新。

reviewText: Risk of Rain is definetely a hard one to review for me.  I find it a rather frustrating game that I continually return to playing and I was left having a hard think on why that is, both in terms of the frustration and in terms of why I keep returning.  Risk of Rain has been something of a mixed bag for me.\n\nSomeone looking at my other reviews - Teleglitch or SotS: The Pit - will see I'm no stranger to roguelike games and I quite enjoy them.  I don't really find them usually too frustrating and they haven't really seen any ragequits.  But Risk of Rain has.  Why is that?  I think it basically comes down to the fact that the feeling I get from the game is very much that the random nature of the game is such that if you do not get favourable drops pretty much fairly all the way through you're going to have a very difficult time even at the normal difficulty.  This wouldn't be so bad if the easy difficulty didn't penalise you for using it - your progression is not saved when you use the easy mode.  I'm of two minds when it comes to that difficulty.  One one hand, the difficulty is one of the definete genre staples of roguelikes.  On the other hand, other roguelikes I've enjoyed had an element of definete skill to them whereby even with a poor random seed you can still get by if you are really, really good.  Risk of Rain definetely feels exceptionally unforgiving in that random aspect.  It's something to bear in mind.  If you're looking for a more rogue light" experience
date: Risk of Rain is definetely not what you are looking for
recommended: but if you enjoy a challenge
hoursPlayed: I think you will probably find that attractive in Risk of Rain.  It definetely has that in spades.\n\nSpeaking of difficulty
voteText: one of the more unique mechanics in Risk of Rain is the idea that the difficulty level increases across incremental levels as time elapses
helpfulPercent: whether or not you are active.  This creates a paltiple tension and as much as I have my difficulty with the random aspect
votesHelpful: this particular aspect is something I really like about the game.  There is no rest break in this game
votesTotal: you have to keep going or something will murder you horribly
votesFunny: and that much definetely is a very roguelike thought indeed.  I quite enjoy that part of it.\n\nThe biggest strength of the game lies in it's audiovisual style however.  It has a very strong and fairly unique aesthetic that is well executed.  I'm actually kind of sad there isn't a soundtrack DLC as I'd buy it in a heartbeat: the soundtrack is utterly captivating and very well composed.  The game itself uses a very "retro" pixel art style
commentsCount: but pulls it off well
column16: and the art in some of the monster logs available through the menu are very well-done examples of that particular style.  I just adore the aesthetic of the game
column17: and when I sit and consider why I keep coming back
column18: its to delve a little more into that world and the lore that surrounds it.  It's strange for a roguelike but I get a definete feeling of exploration in learning the environment and it's lore.\n\nAll in all
column19: it's a very difficult game so if you're looking for a more casual experience

reviewText:
It is not uncommon for human beings to find themselves bored with the monotony of regular life. Day after day we find ourselves experiencing new things, yet we still long for something. We feel as if we need an escape from the world in which we find ourselves. This need has given rise to a plethora of movies, books, and games, among many other things, to distract us from our life. It is with this same feeling that I decided to embark upon such a distraction.

Leaping forth to immerse myself in a new world, I was excited at the new possibilities it offered. Although my character's landing had been rough, I was optimistic for the future. What never before seen wonders would I uncover. What beauty that had yet to grace the sight of man would I be blessed to lay my eyes upon? The imagination of man falls short in the face reality and I knew not what I would come across. The wonderous awe I felt as my feet touched the ground of this new world would be torn brutally away. Naïvety soon wears out its welcome, as did I apparently.

What followed was a quick and horrifying descent into madness. As I gazed upon the flora of this new world, never having seen comparable beauty in Earth's, I was soon greeted with the fauna. A surprising variety of creatures met me with death in their minds. I fought as hard as I could, killing many, but the longer I lingered, the more arrived and the more dangerous they were. An endless flood of enemies assailed me, precious little time was I safe.

Worse still were the monsters who were so much greater than the others. Towering beasts of great strength and tenacity hunted me down. Desperation seeped deep into my bones and I began to savour those rare moments when the creatures of a new area had yet to discover my presence.I would watch as the many different beings who so oft fell dead before me lived. They went about their bussiness, so similar to the animals of Earth.

Realization struck me, I was the alien in this world, the terrifying invader. I represented an outside force that, if I was being totally honest, would in all likelyhood destroy this world's life for greed.

It allowed me to take a step back and gain a new perspective on my existence. 'My' fight for survival, humanity's fight for survival, comes at a great cost. What right did I have to murder so many, just so I could continue on? In what way can I justify so many lives lost for my own? The same can be said for us as a whole. We slaughter our way through countless animals without a second thought. We do not visit new land, we destory it. We do not give to this world, we take from it.

It's an eye-opening experience in which everyone should partake. This game is no mere escape, it is a wake up call.

Scared and confused by my new outlook on life, I was in a daze. My only consolation whilst traversing this desolate virtual land... it never rained.

reviewText:
Hello, I am here to tell you about Risk of rain, a sidescrolly, itemy roguelite that has a trailer so confusing and uninformative that I wouldn't have picked it up if I hadn't heard about it before.

-Important Sidenote! I am not critiquing the game, merely reviewing it.-

In Risk of Rain you are a traveler on a space courier ship that's attacked by a mysterious... thing. Causing you to fall to the ground of an unfamiliar alien planet, where you fight for your life. Picking up items dropped by the ship and ultimately finding your way back to the fallen ship to fight the menace and leave the planet.
When you first go into the game, you walk around the landscape and monsters will start to spawn, though slowly at first. You will then kill them, as they threaten your life, picking up their gold, which you then use to buy items out of the chests that have fallen down with you. When you first start playing, you will only have a small selection of items to find, but as you play more, you will unlock more, and these are persistant across lives. The difficulty increases over time, making monsters tougher and making them spawn more often, until you either die, or finish the game.

So, is it good?
Hell yes. It definitely is fun to play. It has a nice growth curve towards the start, both with unlocking items through achievements" -eg
recommended: or activate the third teleporter without taking damage- and through increases in player skill
hoursPlayed: both with the game and with it's myriad of classes. Classes that

Expect to die in your first few runs.

The items are fun to use

reviewText: A rather short game with a big replayability value that proves how the smallest and most unlikely teams can make great pieces of art. The premise is rather simple, and not something we haven't seen before, but the way it's put in practice just makes Risk of Rain unique and outstanding. In first hand, we have the different characters, each one with his or her unique playstyle, gimmicks and skills, which makes is satisfying to struggle with an initial character that may not be ideal for you for some time, as you get such a high payback for it. Some of these characters are pretty straightforward, packing what you'd expect from them, while others shoot away from expectations, and surprisingly don't lose sense. Another strong point to be seen is the variety in the items, and how they are not linear. You see items like the Soldier's Syringe, the Warbanner and the Lens-Maker's Glasses in the most common tier, while being some of the most useful, and things that have debatable quality, such as the Shattering Justice, in the rarest tier. Apart from your usual items, we have Relics, which are obtained in unique challenges exclusive to each particular level in the game, and can be turned on or off after being acquired. These special items can drastically change gameplay, strong examples being the Glass relic, that amps up your damage to 500% (or five times) the original, but scales your starting health to 10% of the original, the Honor relic, that makes every enemy in the game (including bosses) spawn as an elite monster, which means it will have an extra gimmick to kill you, and the Spirit relic, that multiplies your speed when your health is lower, the game-changing aspect of this one being that it applies to every creature on the world, not only you. To end the item talk"

reviewText: All the other reviews on the store page will tell you its genre and gameplay mechanics, so you already know all about how awesome those are.  Instead, I'll tell you about what will happen after you obtain this game and try it out:\n\nFirst, you'll be a little overwhelmed by the enemies and quickly advancing difficulty.  But, you'll figure out a good strategy or two for taking on some enemies, and feel pretty good about it.  Perhaps this wasn't a bad purchase
date:
you'll think.

Second, you'll begin to realize that several hours have passed and you have started over a few times.  You have two full rows of items at your disposal and you're going back through the first level for the second time.  You'll wonder if perhaps you should go to bed.

Third and finally, you'll experience a burning desire to play this game when you have some free time.  You'll listen to the soundtrack regularly because it's so delicious, and you'll see little item or teleporter outlines when you close your eyes at night.  You'll be able to identify and name all the items you see by icon alone, in no time.

It's really a wonderful game!  I had no idea, until I got sucked in.

reviewText: A rather short game with a big replayability value that proves how the smallest and most unlikely teams can make great pieces of art. The premise is rather simple, and not something we haven't seen before, but the way it's put in practice just makes Risk of Rain unique and outstanding. In first hand, we have the different characters, each one with his or her unique playstyle, gimmicks and skills, which makes is satisfying to struggle with an initial character that may not be ideal for you for some time, as you get such a high payback for it. Some of these characters are pretty straightforward, packing what you'd expect from them, while others shoot away from expectations, and surprisingly don't lose sense. Another strong point to be seen is the variety in the items, and how they are not linear. You see items like the Soldier's Syringe, the Warbanner and the Lens-Maker's Glasses in the most common tier, while being some of the most useful, and things that have debatable quality, such as the Shattering Justice, in the rarest tier. Apart from your usual items, we have Relics, which are obtained in unique challenges exclusive to each particular level in the game, and can be turned on or off after being acquired. These special items can drastically change gameplay, strong examples being the Glass relic, that amps up your damage to 500% (or five times) the original, but scales your starting health to 10% of the original, the Honor relic, that makes every enemy in the game (including bosses) spawn as an elite monster, which means it will have an extra gimmick to kill you, and the Spirit relic, that multiplies your speed when your health is lower, the game-changing aspect of this one being that it applies to every creature on the world, not only you. To end the item talk"
date: we have the only clear and "static" disadvantage of the game: it is highly gear dependant
recommended: which means you might not go far if you don't have a good range of items to choose from (which is basically what you start to work with)

reviewText:
When I first saw this game I didn't know If I was going to like it. . . I'm weary over games with graphics like this and side-scroller shooters. . . now I am Hooked. . . The game is hard. Really hard, yet very simple in design.

This is one of those games that it is ok to die for the game is fair and as you play you unlock tools to help you progress.

The rewards are high and the replay-ability is quite high.

The game changes up every time you play and you can let the game become harder as you feel fit.

The achievements, when gotten feel like you have really earned that achievement.

All and all one of the best games I bought thus far.

I'm very happy that this game came as a pleasant surprise.

I will say a few things on the other side.

Sometimes the controls do seem to derp but not often.

The game can cause some levels of frustration but I do like that some might not.

I do recommend playing with an Xbox controller. . but can be ok with playing with a keyboard.

If you get it have fun.

It may look like it's a small package but it is huge and the images don't really let you know how fun this game can be. .. it is fine solo and awesome with a group. ..

reviewText:
Is for games like Risk Of Rain, each i day think Indies are the future!

In Risk Of Rain we did crashed on weird strange planet full of monsters anf loot to find and the teleporters you so desperately need to get back to your now scuffed up transport ship to get out of dodge, and in order to do that we need to survive a wave of 3min and kill all the monsters! It features beautiful pixel art and a awesome soundtrack. Besides Single Player, you can enjoy it in local or online co-op mode, witch can be much harder.

There are 10 classes to choose from but only 1 is available at start. The other class you will unlock when you complete some task (some can bit a hard), but right from the begging you have the Comando Class, witch is nice class to use, it has a nice set of skill and you can easily complete the game with that.

All class are good in their own way, a quick example would be the Enforcer, since it has a shield can take more damaged.

But it lacks in one thing, the replay value is good but after a while gets boring because the world are always the same, i would wish if we had more world to explore and kills those monsters.  But with the awesome SP, COOP and the lovely OST this game is must!

~ 9/10

reviewText:
I honestly love this game. Risk of Rain is a rogue-like, action platformer game with a bunch of content. Risk of Rain has over 40 monsters (or enemies) including the elite ones, with 15 bosses that will constantly keep spawning and attacking you. The spawn rate of enemies will increase as you continue your adventure in the foreign planet. The game itself is really challenging and difficult to play, and that's good to see as I like to challenge myself in rogue-like games.

Multiplayer is great. I had a lot of fun with one of my friend who apparently broke the game by continously getting an item that decreases the cooldown of use items by 25% everytime he saw a red chest.

Singleplayer is a bit meh to me. Singleplayer is honestly just boring for me and there is no fun to it in my opinion. I honestly would prefer to have friends with you to play this game, as it makes the game a lot more easier and exciting to play.

This game is really buggy. Sometimes, I randomly crash for no reason or when a lot of things are happening on my screen that causes me to lag like hell, but it honestly doesn't ruin the gameplay for me.

Great game. Would recommend to anyone. 69/10.

reviewText:
Similar Games:

Super Smash Bros, The Binding of Isaac and to a lesser degree Terraria

The Good:

A fun mix of a roguelike action platformer with boss battles thrown in.
The artwork, while sticking to the retro trend, still manages to be impressive.
The item variation is well-designed with unique names and artwork for each.
The timer element definitely increases the tension as well as the excitement as the game progresses.
Similar to The Binding of Isaac, the items you find can make the difference between “a good run” and a fairly quick and brutal death.
Levels are quasi-randomized, adding to the unique feel of each run.
Multiplayer is a ton of fun (although with a caveat – see The Bad).
Higher difficulty levels/later stages get just plain crazy with the amount of carnage on the screen (again, with a caveat – see The Bad).
The playable characters vary greatly, with the unlockable ones requiring a fair amount of skill to play.
The game allows you to beat the game in a “straight run” or revisit earlier levels to farm items before attempting the last boss.
The music fits the atmosphere of the game perfectly, although after a couple playthroughs you’ll be wishing there was more than a handful of tracks.

The Bad:

The jump timing is a bit off. More than a few times, I’ve missed a simple jump because the game couldn’t process that I was hitting move and spacebar simultaneously.
Multiplayer is more fun than single player, however…
Multiplayer has a number of bugs: 1) If you die, sometimes you can’t switch between spectating the remaining players 2) The boss timer tends to display different information to each player, e.g. I’ll see the timer has finished while the other player sees 15 seconds, etc 3) A fairly cryptic error message will sometimes appear in the upper left corner of the screen, then disappear.
The multiplayer lobby needs a few tweaks, such as leaving the IP visible, letting players re-select characters, showing character names/abilities, etc.
Once you reach higher difficulty levels and/or the final stage, the game lags horribly due to the amount of items on-screen at once.
A game running on Steam in 2013 requiring a direct IP connection makes no sense.
This game does not like alt-tabbing.
Sometimes the game just crashes for no apparent reason.
The Writing:

Most roguelikes skimp on the writing, but Risk of Rain actually has a fair amount of quality writing contained in the item log. Aside from that, the writing is limited to randomized one-liners when multiplayer participants die, half of which sound like they were written by someone either in middle school or from ♥♥♥♥♥.

Did I make time to complete it?

Definitely – although The Bad may seem to outweigh The Good, this game is still one of my top games of 2013. I’ve played Risk of Rain since the beta, and the full Steam version for over 16 hours.

Recommended Purchase Price:

This game is *easily* worth $9.99 – I’d pay $20 without hesitation.

or

200% of current retail value of $9.99

Reviewer:

Mudlab

http://www.gamersglance.com

reviewText:
The game has quite much potential, it's fun to play and its rogue-like elements work. Unfortunately it doesn't give very polished impression... some things in the game are carried out in ways that are sub-par. I initially tried playing the game on Arch Linux, but the x360 controller didn't work with the game (whereas it worked fine for example with Hammerwatch), so I changed to Windows. All games were played online.

The biggest problem was that the Last boss teleporter crashed the game every time it was tried, which is game breaking. How can a game have so critical bug? In a roguelike it's utterly ridiculous that the game rewards the player always with error screen instead of last boss after 30 min of gameplay... no report option but just plaintext error. In a game where you start from the beginning after death, this is very frustrating.

The game also had problems starting online coop which crashed the game twice. Before that the online game had some connection issues and the other player couldn't connect.

Also, for some unexplainable reason, the enemies and other player started warping on one occasion. The ping is shown corner of the screen and it didn't really explain these warping issues. In this occasion the game played surprisingly well but things appeared somewhere where they shouldn't have.

I'd really like to give this game a chance. Its gameplay is quite nice and fun but it appears to be broken. There may or may not be a fix for the gamebreaker, but it shouldn't be gamer's job to first keep googling for hours a solutions and after that keep playing half an hour just to see if the first one (or tenth one) solution had actually worked.

EDIT: After ten more hours of gameplay and six more random crashes. The game keeps crashing quite often, about one time in a hour and a half. This means that every third run or so crashes.
Besides that the coop has that last boss can't be fought because of that teleport bug.

Also during these hours of gameplay the biggest problem of the game concept was revealed. The game has quite many items to unlock, but unlocking them doesn't really give awarding feeling. The biggest accomplishment of Binding of Isaac was that gamer experienced the unlockables awarding. In Isaac each unlockable gave a chance to get further in the game and completing the game gave new levels. In Risk of Rain the game can be completed with basic layout, so there isn't really need for cool new items. Also the waves that get more difficult as the time of a run proceeds don't differ from each other enough. I tought that after the waves I see you" and "I'm coming for you" something unbeatable would have appeared. Instead just more enemies come and some low level boss enemies that can be easily farmed for powerups. The game doesn't award for speed in runs
recommended: which really doesn't suit this game."

reviewText:
Super fun rougelike platformer where sometimes you become the boss.

Rougelikes are like jaw breakers, eventually you'll get through. In RoR, success is found through item and character synergy. At the beginning you sometimes have a chance to buy items that will shore up your character's weaknesses. For example, Commando (your first character) has excellent attack speed, but needs damage. Mortars and missiles are priority here.

There's always going to be a mob on your trail. Kiting (attacking, running, attacking) is essential to staying alive. Your drones and items will help you out, but at some point it's up to you to not jump into that death pit and insta-die. If you're flailing hard, try the Community Guides (link below).

Every round is different thanks to the plethora of items and characters. There's a lot to try here. It's definitely worth it.


Community Guides:
http://steamcommunity.com/app/248820/guides/
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I had had my eye on this one for a while, and when a friend asked me if I wanted to play I impulse bought it on the spot. It turned out to be not only one of my best sale purchases this holiday season, but one of the better games I have played in a long time.

It is essentially a hardcore roguelike styled action platformer, shortform and with huge amounts of replayability due to colectables, quite a wealth of characters with 4 different abilities each and a plethora of items to unlock and pick up.

- Story: There is not much of an initial story except for the opening cinematic, but as you unlock more characters and monster logs through the game more of the story is filled in. At no point was there a moment where I had to stop and look at the story so far, as it is an action platformer ultimately rather than some long winded fantasy sci-fi epic, but the way the devs have filled in bits of story via logs and such is quite well done.

- Sound: Music wise, the developers have chosen quite apt styles of music for the different stages, while creating an atmosphere that suits the gameplay and themes quite well. The sound effects are something else though; each enemy has an attacking noise, as do the weapons and powerups you accrue, and eventually you get to know the sounds of each. This doesn't sound like much, but in a game such as this these sounds are both well fitting and incredibly useful to keep track of enemies in your vicinity.

- Gameplay: I think of this as a side scrolling version of Binding of Isaac meets Super House of Dead Ninjas, with an added layer (or 40) of difficulty.Each playthrough is different and items per each run can make or break it for you, as they can in BoI. However, the mechanics and verticality are far more similar to SHoDN, with things being frantic on the screen most of the time. All of this combined makes the game quite fun to play through, and I highly recommend it.

As always, it is perhaps best to watch videos of the game before buying, and it is rather difficult alone. If you have a couple of friends to play with it is an absolute blast, and after you unlock a few things playing solo is also quite doable. As of yet I have not gotten to/beat the final stage/boss, but even after I have I will keep playing to unlock more items that become available. Definitely a recommended purchase.

This was my first reviews as well, hope it helps someone out there!
