reviewText:
Overall, I recommend this. For the 10 dollars that it's worth it's definitely worth it. It's simple but fun. There's a wide variety of items, enemies (including bosses), and stages. It's the type of game you can pick up and play for hours and not get bored, and even manage to find more things. I don't have much time played on it, but given the nature of the game and how there's so much to collect, I'll definitely be playing it for a while.

Every item seems overpowered, but there's so many that you really can't stick to one overall play style every time you play, which adds to the fun because instead of the game adapting to your play style, you have to adapt your play style to what you're given.

There's also a wide variety of enemies with many different levels of difficulty, and also overwhelm you at times, which add to the overall feel of the game by giving it a sense of urgency.

To restate the thesis, I definitely recommend this, and it's worth the money spent.

reviewText:
(TL;DR: What are you doing reading this, buy it now gogogogogogo)

Risky Rain is a game where you play as a guy called Commander Risky. The plot is you and some other people are space mailmen, trying to deliver ♥♥♥♥ when your ship starts exploding and crash lands on a planet, and then you have to get back to it before the space monsters surely eat your flesh.

The game has three main difficulties, ranging from cup of water to Atlantic Ocean, and has a difficulty timer in game that starts at 2ez, and then just laughs at you for the highest one for some reason.

There are 9 other persons who you can play as if you do some stuff, with my favorite being Handy, the robot janitor (I like him because he has a hammer). There's also these weird black rocks that make the game play all weirdly, so use them at your own risk (HEHEH, GEDDIT!?).

the gameplay consists of running around trying to not get killed. When you kill the monsters, they drop money and glowy balls, which make your life numbers bigger. To survive however, you need to use the money to lockpick boxes and buy stuff from vending machines. you can play this by yourself, or with other people sitting next you (player cap 4) or with people from the internets (up to 10 with settings adjustments! WOW!).

all in all, I give this hard fun game 2 potatoes out of 3 apples.

reviewText: Its been a while since I have made a recommendation, and for good reason.  I only make recommendations when I whole heartedly believe the game is not good, but truely spectacular in my mind.  This game encapsulates the rougelike genre and seemlessly moulds it together with a platformer. reviewText:
Awesome game that I wish lasted longer. Really hoping the Devs have intentions of adding on to this game. With around 10 good runs you can get every character. Each person brings something different to the table, making multiplayer a blast. Late game gets redonk with the sheer amount of monsters on the map, usually the last map, causing severe drops in the games speed (note:nothing to do with my RIG, simply the vast amount of crap happening at once).  Annoying that muliplayer is a hassel to do since you have to do port forwarding (which is a plague) unless you get lazy and just use Hamachi, etc.

Whilst it says randomly generated it's more a the maps are always the same (The randomly selected maps are the 2nd and 3rd map which is swapped with a whole 2 other maps) with MINOR variations and the only REAL RNG is the random crate placement.

Multiplayer is fun but it seems that if you don't stay together you lose or one person gets all the items (they don't  compensate for more people by adding more items so it's already a Negative for multiplayer)  and carries the others since they insta die on the next level.

the gameplay consists of running around trying to not get killed. When you kill the monsters, they drop money and glowy balls, which make your life numbers bigger. WOW!).

all in all, I give this hard fun game 2 potatoes out of 3 apples.

reviewText:
Overall, I recommend this. For the 10 dollars that it's worth it's definitely worth it. It's simple but fun. There's a wide variety of items, enemies (including bosses), and stages. It's the type of game you can pick up and play for hours and not get bored, and even manage to find more things. I don't have much time played on it, but given the nature of the game and how there's so much to collect, I'll definitely be playing it for a while.

Every item seems overpowered, but there's so many that you really can't stick to one overall play style every time you play, which adds to the fun because instead of the game adapting to your play style, you have to adapt your play style to what you're given.

There's also a wide variety of enemies with many different levels of difficulty, and also overwhelm you at times, which add to the overall feel of the game by giving it a sense of urgency.

To restate the thesis, I definitely recommend this, and it's worth the money spent.

reviewText:
Super fun rougelike platformer where sometimes you become the boss.

Rougelikes are like jaw breakers, eventually you'll get through. In RoR, success is found through item and character synergy. At the beginning you sometimes have a chance to buy items that will shore up your character's weaknesses. For example, Commando (your first character) has excellent attack speed, but needs damage. Mortars and missiles are priority here.

There's always going to be a mob on your trail. Kiting (attacking, running, attacking) is essential to staying alive. Your drones and items will help you out, but at some point it's up to you to not jump into that death pit and insta-die. If you're flailing hard, try the Community Guides (link below).

Every round is different thanks to the plethora of items and characters. There's a lot to try here. It's definitely worth it.


Community Guides:
http://steamcommunity.com/app/248820/guides/
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I had had my eye on this one for a while, and when a friend asked me if I wanted to play I impulse bought it on the spot. It turned out to be not only one of my best sale purchases this holiday season, but one of the better games I have played in a long time.

It is essentially a hardcore roguelike styled action platformer, shortform and with huge amounts of replayability due to colectables, quite a wealth of characters with 4 different abilities each and a plethora of items to unlock and pick up.

- Story: There is not much of an initial story except for the opening cinematic, but as you unlock more characters and monster logs through the game more of the story is filled in. At no point was there a moment where I had to stop and look at the story so far, as it is an action platformer ultimately rather than some long winded fantasy sci-fi epic, but the way the devs have filled in bits of story via logs and such is quite well done.

- Sound: Music wise, the developers have chosen quite apt styles of music for the different stages, while creating an atmosphere that suits the gameplay and themes quite well. The sound effects are something else though; each enemy has an attacking noise, as do the weapons and powerups you accrue, and eventually you get to know the sounds of each. This doesn't sound like much, but in a game such as this these sounds are both well fitting and incredibly useful to keep track of enemies in your vicinity.

- Gameplay: I think of this as a side scrolling version of Binding of Isaac meets Super House of Dead Ninjas, with an added layer (or 40) of difficulty.Each playthrough is different and items per each run can make or break it for you, as they can in BoI. However, the mechanics and verticality are far more similar to SHoDN, with things being frantic on the screen most of the time. All of this combined makes the game quite fun to play through, and I highly recommend it.

As always, it is perhaps best to watch videos of the game before buying, and it is rather difficult alone. If you have a couple of friends to play with it is an absolute blast, and after you unlock a few things playing solo is also quite doable. As of yet I have not gotten to/beat the final stage/boss, but even after I have I will keep playing to unlock more items that become available. Definitely a recommended purchase.

This was my first reviews as well, hope it helps someone out there!

reviewText: I would recommend to anyone whos likes a challenge and good things. Insanely fun and addicting. The soundtrack of this game is submersive and ominous, but the game gets really intense listening to your own music. Sound effects are retro but not annoying, you can almost feel the explosions hitting your enemies and the sounds of bullets hitting their flesh.\nI have never enjoyed the idea of perma-death but this game has opened up that genre to me, it does a great job of making you feel like ever playable charcter is different, and the speed at which the difficulty, as well as your own strength, on each playthrough provides for excellent fast-action that is really addicting. And on top of everything its online an local multiplayer!\nThe atmosphere and small shreds of story we get from this game are excellent builing blocks for a game that question the human vs. nature relationship, this is built from assumptions incredibly sparce dialogue, and the tormented thoughts of a lone survivor adrift a hostile planet. While these intriguing elements of story and atmosphere are present, they are not so in-your-face
date: rather, appearing in monster and item descriptions, these small attention to detail is immersive, interesting and not at all distracting of the core game. A perfect balance of incredibly strong replay value, and a good incentive to keep playing to unlock this worlds story, which we end up caring a lot about.\nThe graffics are very charming and pleasing to the eye. No matter what of the 10 characters you play, your are always a small  pile of about 30 pixels. Not to say that they were lazy at all, no. Rather, the simplicty and smallness of your charcter is great to look at and really makes your feel small in a world of things trying to kill you. The monsters are the same way, though they are larger than you(some very much so), they feel like true inhabitants of the world youve landed in. Bosses feel and look powerful and their deaths are satisfying. Graphically the world around you looks amazing, like the remnants of an ancient alien civilization. They really put you in concern with your characters need to survive.\nOverall, I give this game a 9/10. The reason not a perfect score is the only could use some tweaking. The difficulty, graphics, upgrades, items, collectables and secrets keep me coming back for more everytime I sit down to my computer. Never, have I put so many hours so quickly into a game that was inly $10. It was worth every cent twofold

reviewText:
A very fun randomly generated rogue-like side-scroller. The ten different characters each have a different set of attacks allowing for different play styles, from long range single target damage to melee crowd control. Different items augment your character in a variety of way, from healing with each hit, firing missiles on hitting an enemy or raining meteorites down when you use it. Artifacts also alter the way the game plays once unlocked, allowing for extra challenge.

The goal of each level is simple, find the teleporter, activate it, hold out against the spawning enemies and boss/es and get to the next level until the finale. As time goes by the difficulty increases, meaning enemies get tougher and bosses will start spawning randomly, this forces you to balance between collecting items but risk increasing the difficulty or go as fast as you can while losing out on items and not being as powerful. Combat-wise the game is simple but is not easy, careful use and timing of your abilities is key to survivng against the alien hordes.

The game has solo play, local co-op or online co-op (The online lacks UPnP and so requires port forwarding). This is a great game, and is better if you can play co-op.

reviewText:
Risk of Rain is an enjoyable Rogue-Like action focused platformer with a great soundtrack. Although it has slight problems with game life and multiplayer, I suggest buying this game. Now we shall go onto the specifics of the game.

Risk of Rain is a Rogue-Like platformer that has 10 classes; each of these classes has 4 different skill sets allowing for a very diverse game experience. There are 11 different areas in the game, each with a few different stage layouts. Not every session the player plays will actually consist of all 11 areas. Most sessions, players will only see 5 stages. Each stage is laid out very well that isn't confusing nor unfair for combat.

The combat of the game is very strong. It also can remain diverse because of the different classes. Each class possses a different skill set that can be used for different situation. The Commando, being the starting class, is the most all around class in the game. The Sniper, being an unlocked class, is the most situational class in the whole game being that it is a boss killer.

Like FTL and Rogue Legacy, the game can get tiring faster than wanted. I played about 3 hours on the day of purchase because of its solid gameplay. As the week continued, the desire to play the game and the amount of time spent started to dwindle. I found that after the intial high of the game, I really didn't have a huge desire to play the game. That doesn't mean that Risk of Rain is a bad game. The multiplayer can easily increase the life of the game

This brings up another problem with Risk of Rain. The multiplayer is not very simple to set up. You have to go through and get your IP and open ports up on your computer. The hardcore computer gamer should be capable of doing this with no problem, but that doesn't mean that the process is not annoying. Dying in multiplayer can also make it a very boring game if playing with someone who is much better. There is no way to revive your friends; all you can do is beat the level or die. All they can do is watch and hope you die.

To conclude the review, Risk of Rain is an enjoyable Rogue-Like action focused platformer with a great soundtrack. Although it has slight problems with game life and multiplayer, I suggest buying this game. Now we shall go onto the specifics of the game.

reviewText:
I love this game. It is one of the best platformers I've played. It has the pixel art feel that seems kind of more normal these days in indie games, but I like that, who cares, but the thing I really like about the art is when you get the monster logs. The way they do the art on there is the only time I have seen that style of art.

The game's idea and gameplay is amazing. You are stuck on a planet because Providence (Guy from the opening cutscene) crashes your ship and fills it with monsters. You land on a planet as one of the ship's cargo... things. You then fight off strange monsters to open chests, give money to shrines, and kill imps to get items, which all have their unique visual effect and ablility. The cool thing about these items is that all the items have their own logs, showing where they came from, what the note on it was, etc. This is because like I previously stated (Did I?) you were on a cargo ship.

Every world usually has unique monsters and sometimes a different map format than the previous one. You need to loot all the things there as fast as possible, activate the teleporter, fend off hordes and hordes of enemies and maybe a boss or 7 (The Holy Temple at the highest level... SO MANY TOXIC BEASTS AND IMP OVERLORDS!) until the timer runs out, then you kill all the enemies yadda yadda yadda... Then you go to the next level.

The combat system is one of my favourites since you have to master the characters or just be skilled at them, because smashing buttons will not work, hence the first time I played enforcer. You may think melee characters are terrible, but once you unlock the acrid you will regret saying that.

reviewText: This game kills me and every part of my soul and well-being, then taunts me about it. I just keep going in to getrekt, and anyone who plays this will know of the addiction I speak of. Risk of Rekt's goal is very simple- Get to the final stage, defeat the final boss. On the way there, you have to fight your way through a good number of varied enemies and bosses that spawn from activating the teleporter and, on harder difficulties, that spawn randomly. The method is to do it all as quick as possible, to keep the difficulty bar from mocking you further(eventually reaching HAHAHAHAHA difficulty).\nEach character class has 4 skills that are specific to the type of character, and there are 8 classes in all so far, so it won't be too difficult to find one to be attuned to. Along with the class skills, there are also items that help some characters more than others. By going through the levels and collecting items, the player becomes stronger. With the game still updating every now and then, there are even more enemies, classes, and items to be introduced. There's never a dull moment while playing Risk of Rekt, even when you die, you jump right back in and start wreaking havoc. It's a game that's easily addicting and even more fun when you play with friends, and I'd reccomend this to anyone(whether you have friends or not) because it's definitely worth a go. Or, you know, 500 gos. However long it takes you to beat the final boss! But even after you beat the boss, you're going to want to play again and again to get better.

reviewText: Play this game. Seriously. Gorgeous pixel art, awesome soundtrack, very satisfying SFXs. At 10$ it is so worth it. It IS a roguelike, so you will be more at ease if you're familiar with The Binding of Isaac and even more so with Rogue Legacy, but with three difficulty settings it will suit you whatever your skill with these games.\nIs it hard? Incredibly. Is it fair? Absolutely. Is it rewarding? Immensely. Is it fun? You bet your ♥♥♥ it is.\nAll of this already makes it a must-play, but the fact that it has 4 player coop, local or online, is so awesome. If you have 3 friends to play this with, get ready to spend hours screaming at the top of your lungs while you and your friends barely survive a never-ending onslaught of increasingly tough enemies. I know I will.

reviewText:
I really wasn't expecting this amount of fun.  It has an almost perfect balance of skill requirement, a good difficulty curve, and the reward of unlockable content and the feeling of accomplishment when you succeed, with a dash of luck required to spice things up.
The artstyle is interesting and each creature and item has it's own entry in a log accessed from the main menu, so if you're not playing the game you can look at some interesting background for it as well as some cool artwork of the enemies/bossies, provided you've picked up their log in-game.

There's also enough unlockables to make you want to continue playing, if the gameplay wasn't enough for you, and a number of unique(ish) classes to change your game each time.  Throw in a few buddies and you've got a great co-op adventure.

Finally, the music sets the tone perfectly - I'd buy the soundtrack if it becomes available (it may already be, I should go check...)

At first glance, you might think paying 10 or even 7 bucks for this is too much. Well, I thought that as well, but I soon realized I would pay double what I had if I knew it was going to be this fun!

This is the hardest-hitting, most action-packed roguelite in my library. The art and soundtrack are incredible, and the ten unlockable characters provide tons of replayability. 9/10: get this game!

reviewText: Risk of rain is a fiendishly difficult 2d shooter with roguelike inspirations. The game starts out fairly simple, you're on an alien planet, and need to find a teleporter. The first stage of the game is not too rough, however, as time progresses, regardless of your progress, enemies begin to ramp up in number and strength. This creates a dilemna, do you throughly search a level for items and monsters to kill for experience? Or do you rush the teleporter, fight the boss, and move on quickly? It's these decisions along with many fun characters to experiment playing with that make Risk of Rain shine. If you're a fan of 2D shooters, or roguelikes and don't mind dying many times over in many situations, definitely make time for this game.

reviewText:
Aahh , Risk of Rain , where do i start ...

First of all , this game may seem hard at first , but trust me , more and more you play , you will get the hang of it. This game is basically a run-and-gun with rogue-like elements. With 12 classes , each with 4 unique abilities , you wont get bord so fast. And dont forget the items , which are a lot too. The game may have some bugs , which is not nice , but you can get over them. And i almost forgot , everything is randomly generated , so no 2 runs would be the same.

Now , regarding classes , my favorite part of the game. You start at first with only 1 basic class. Yep , only 1 class out of 12. You must do certain things to unlock classes , like killing bosses , reaching a certain level or in some cases even finding the other characters hidden in the game's levels. No 2 classes are the same , each one of them has an unique playstyle and set of abilities . For example , there is the sniper who excels at firing precise shots , being very good for dealing with bosses , but not so good for dealing with hordes of enemies. Or the enforcer , a tank who can stun enemies , or block all frontal damage with his shield.

Now the items. Oh boy , there are lots of items . Some give you a shield , some make your attacks explode . There are activable items who can summon ghosts to fight for you , shoot a lot of missles and so on.

The enemies in this game are well done , every stage bringing some new type of enemy . And also , you can buy drones to help you out in your journey . These drones fly near you and shoot the bad guys or heal you.

And the soundtrack ? Pure genius.

TL;DR Get this game if you like rogue like shooters with lots of classes and items , and most of all , good replay value.

reviewText:
Risk of Rain is quite the entertaining platformer rogue-like. What I particulary enjoyed, was;
-The characters. Even though I cannot play some of them, such as Sniper or Engineer, they were quite fun to unlock.
-The simple objectives. Although the game is so simple, of which all you need to do is find the teleporter and eradicate any remaining enemies, you know how to play Commando, itemwise and abilitywise.
-The replayability. No matter how many different characters you have unlocked, or how many times you've beaten the game, you always can play it much more than you thought. It isn't something where you have to mod it to be able to play it again (Yes, I'm talking about you, Minecraft.), instead, it teaches you more about the characters you play, and what items are best for  them.
-The soundtrack. This, made me so immersed into the game, from what I had seen in TotalBiscuit's review of RoR, really stood out. I turn my volume to 0%, and my Music to 100% in the game options. I just fight on, using every artifact or a few, listening to the soundtrack.
-The final fight. This can get annoying if you don't set up a strategy, much like the game Spiral Knights, when you are fighting the Royal Jelly on the 5-2 mission 'The Soverign Slime', you will get destroyed. I set up a tactic, as I had read about Providence after getting destroyed on my fight with him.
Overall, everything is well-made.

reviewText:
One of the best games I have played.
The absolute best rogue-like game I have ever played.
If you want:
*A Fun challenge of progression for every death
*A Ton of unlockable items to unlock
*A Variety of 10 different classes (2 more arriving soon enough according to their website)
*A fast-paced, action-filled and thrilling gameplay, of being afraid you will get destroyed within the next 5 seconds, which makes you focus even harder

- and not to forget
*An absolutely outstanding soundtrack
then I can only say that, Risk of Rain is a game for you!

Oh... and I almost forgot about the artifacts that are hidden throughout the different maps, which just changes the gameplay to something entirely different, and opens up for so much more content!

I have one bad thing to say... I want more content. This does not mean that the game does not actually contain a lot of stuff, because it does. I just can't get enough of it! It did take me some time to complete it 100%, including all achievements, so it's not because I haven't got the €9 of gameplay that I payed for. Because in my eyes, that's a freaking bargain!

Anyways:

Short version: For €9, this is a bargain. Much gameplay. Amazing game. I WANT MORE! 10/10

reviewText: Fantastic game, if you are a fan of games such as The Binding of Isaac, Paranautical Activity, or even Spelunky, you should really take a look at this game. With a variety of characters to unlock, randomized levels, numerous bosses and an assortment of items to pick up, the game is packed with hours upon hours of Rogue-lite fun. Something I found quite interesting in this game was the ability to stack multiple of the same items, to the point where you're zapping everything in sight by jamming on your Ukulele or have enough regen to shrug off most any attack, should luck be on your side. While Risk of Rain is a blast to play solo, the inclusion of a multiplayer mode going up to 4 players (Local or Online) gives this game just that much more staying power. Playing solo or with friends, this is a must buy if you are a fan of Rogue-lite games with just a hint of platforming.

reviewText:
Risk of rain is fantastic!

The game has a very simple yet detailed pixel art style, and interesting monster, weapon, and character designs, each masterfully animated.

The music seems to be inspired by retro game beats, yet feels fresh, and oscillates from being adreniline pumping, to calm and relaxing, it's a good, fun, varied sountrack.

The simple yet deep gameplay, offers various characters to unlock, each offering very unique movesets that all have been perfectly balanced, so one should be able to find one character that fits their playstyle. While the game is hard, it never feels so due to monsters having an unfair advantage, however several artifacts can also be unlocked to alter gameplay so it either ends up easier, or more difficult.

Additionally three difficulty levels can be selected, so you can cater the challenge to your own tastes.

The gist of the game is to fight off a neverending wave of enemies, that become progressively more difficult the longer the game is in play, over the course of 6 levels. Each level is completed by first finding a teleporter, then fighting off against a boss, and surviving a time limit wherein serveral enemies will spawn to attack the player, after successfully doing so the player will be transported to the next level.

A lot of work went into the design of the game, from the easy to navigate menu's, to the environments available, and amount of enemies you can come across, to the games ostensibly simple story that reveals more depth as you dig into the lore.

Along with the many secrets, hidden areas, and unlockables to discover.

Multiplayer is a blast, but unfortunately very difficult to set up with others...

Risk of rain is fun on all levels, and an excellent addition to the indie genre, that should keep one entertained for hours!
Score: 4.5/5
-0.5 due to the difficulty in setting up a multiplayer game.

Sincerely,
- Celx Requin

Website: www.cancer-cinema.com
Twitter: www.twitter.com/cancercinema
Steam Game Page: http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=241984931

reviewText:
Risk of Rain is a 2d platform game where you have to survive in a foreign planet with the aid of the item you find scattered across the planet.After you find the teleporter in a stage,there will be a countdown to when the teleporter will be fully activated.Don't worry,you won't be doing nothing during the countdown.Spawn rate of monster will be increased and the boss will spawn as well.After defeating the monster in the stage,you will be teleported to another stage.Before you enter the final stage,you will get to visit previous stages that you complete(loop).Remember time=difficulty

Pros
-Item varies your gameplay
-Unique character with Unique skills
-Good level of difficulty
-interesting stage mechcenics
-Good amount of items
-active and passive do their part in ensuring your survivor
-multiplayer
-Artifacts That greatly affects your gameplay

Cons
-Limited kinds of enemy
-Somewhat weak boss design
-items are not interesting/unique(items do basic stuff like increase dps/health regen etc)
-Final boss is not thrilling instead i find it boring
-multiplayer do not work well(connection issue/timeout)


You might say that the stage structure generation is not random as a con this is because it is to ensure that the Artifacts are obtainable and accessable

Overall,i think this is a great game and you should get it.However boss fights are boring as yo can scum the boss by getting to a place the boss can't access.I Find myself getting into the game and you probably will

7.5/10 Great game

reviewText:
Pixely roguelikelike with light platforming where you play a tiny dude collecting the scattered loot from their cargo ship and shooting their way off a hostile planet. Great looking pixelart style, fantastic music, controls are quick to grasp, every class plays completely differently, the game is generally hard as balls without being obnoxious or unfair, and you're going to love it when you reach the point of vomiting secondary damage effects and projectiles with every other shot.

There's also a ukelele and the gunslinger dude wears a cowboy hat on top of his e-suit helmet.

It's great both solo and in co-op, play it.

reviewText:
Risk of Rain is a fun little mob/arena/hardashell timepasser. You will die multiple times in the beginning before reaching even level 3, but don't give up the learning curve is not that steep.

Pros-
+Addictive
+Tons Of Items
+Challenging but not unplayable
+Extra Challenges to do
+Collectible Logs
+Fast Pace
+Diverse Group of Characters
+CO-OP is fun and refreshing

Cons-
-Becomes Diffcult very very quick
-You will probably spend alot of your time hiding on a rope waiting for HP or your use item to come back
-Hosting a CO-OP game requires opening a port, making it kind of a nuisance
-You could spend a large amount of time attempting to do a challenge and just end up dying before it gets done

~7/10~

reviewText: Risk of Rain is a truly excellent game with amazing enemy and item variety, well designed and subtley altered levels every game as well as a good selection of characters to pick from. It is a great side scrolling open platformer/shooter/nommer/exploder that keeps you hooked for hours. I will be playing so much more of this game. The soundtrack is sublime, a mix of electronic synths with glockenspiels and metallaphones with time signatures to fry your brains it is worth opening Spotify or Youtube (go to the composer Chris Christodoulou's channel) and listen to the whole thing. Masterpiece.\n\nOne thing of note is the online functionality at time of writing is a mess, unfortunately there is no LAN and the system for connecting requires one to open up ports in their internet, so it is a fiddly process.

reviewText:
It will take a long time for you to get bored of Risk of Rain.  Even though the game length itself is pretty short, you definitely will not win the first time you play due to how difficult it is.  But it's an addictive kind of difficulty, the kind where you immediately fire the game up again after your death, just to see if you can get farther.

Unlockable characters and items definitely help keep things interesting, as does online multiplayer.  If you know how to port forward, multiplayer with even just one other person is a blast.

The fact I can't stop playing it after having bought it says a lot about how fun it is.

reviewText:
I very much enjoyed Risk of Rain.

When I first got the game, with only the Commando as a playable character, I found it harder to enjoy.
The difficulty curve from the start put me off, and I didn't know (and still don't) how to play the Commando well, so I put it aside. After a while, however, I came back to it, and started to unlock more and more characters, which is when I realised that the sense of satisfaction as you climb through levels and acquire a veritable armory of items is very rewarding.

I feel that, skill aside, some characters are simply more effective than others, and that some of the in-game unlockable achievements are unrealistic (Activating the third teleporter without being hurt once just seems unrealistic for a more casual player), but those are the only negatives I can think of. The art style is perhaps left to preference, but I very much enjoy the simplicity and elegance in well-done pixel art, and find it very appealing.

Each character feels unique and plays unique, the simplicity of four skills combined with varying attack and movement speed lending to a completely different playstyle for every character, something that I feel is often lost in current games. The items, some more useful than others, all feel like they have distinct bonuses and different, from the Guardian Hearts to the Jetpacks and the Wicked Rings, and finding a higher-tier item feels rewarding and can immediately change your playstyle.

The levels are, perhaps, not that high in variety, but due to the adaptation in playstyle from each character and the multitude of items, they always feel like they play different. However, once all the characters have been unlocked, and all (or most of) the items, repitition kicks in: but this could be said for any game, so I won't count this as a negative.

All in all, a very enjoyable time waster, allowing for both quick games and intense playthroughs, the mechanics are rewarding, and utilising only four skills per character, they all feel and play wildly different. Definitely recommended.

reviewText:
Another pixelated rogue-like game that does not disappoint!   This game gets progressively harder as the timer counts on, giving a sense of urgency to quickly level up and collect items to better combat the waves of enemies, and bosses.

What's that you say?!  Level up?  That's correct, the enemies drop experience and money; giving the game an RPG element to its action.

You unlock different classes of characters, each with their own specialities and skills.  Also its co-op, and thus the only reason I'm posting this review, so I can get my lazy friends to buy this game, when they'll just be like

reviewText:
Playing Risk of Rain resembles the situation in which your friend tells you to put your hands in a bowl of boiling water.
He says it'll be very hot, and you proceed to place your hands in the bowl.
This isn't hot at all!" you exclaim.
"Just you wait." he says.
Soon
date: the water starts to feel extremely hot
recommended: and you try to pull out your hands
hoursPlayed:
but they are stuck firmly.
You watch your hands melt and burn beneath the quiet water as you stare at it with horrified eyes.
"I told you it would be hot. I told you."
That's what Risk of Rain makes you feel when you play it.
More or less

reviewText: Harkening back to the day of the 8 and 16-bit platformer, Risk of Rain is deliberately inscrutable roguelike that relishes in its masochistic difficulty curve. Skipping any kind of pretence of a tutorial or any of the modern hand-holding gamers have come to expect, your little spaceman is dropped into a random, semi-procedurally generated map with little more than the vague instructions to Find the Teleporter" to go on. Vicious monsters begin to spawn almost immediately and it doesn't take long to realize how hopelessly outmatched your little guy is
date: and it only gets worse from there.\n\nThe central conceit of Risk of Rain
recommended: and what makes it stand out from the pack of other recently released roguelikes
hoursPlayed: is the timer. A large clock in the top right of the screen mercilessly ticks upwards with every second. The longer you take
voteText: the more frequently the monsters spawn
helpfulPercent: and the stronger they grow. Every five minutes
votesHelpful: a bell marks the passing into a higher level of difficulty
votesTotal: starting at "Very Easy" and eventually tipping into the realm of "impossible" and "HAHAHAHAHA." If you haven't been efficient at collecting upgrades and items
votesFunny: you may soon find yourself surrounded on all sides by monsters you don't have a prayer of defeating. The mission quickly turns from "how far can I get?" to "how long can I survive!?"\n\nThere is an incredible sense of urgency packed into every second of RoR because of that timer. Every choice and action becomes crucial. What way to you explore after spawning? Should you stay in this area and try to clear out enough monsters to earn enough gold to open another chest
commentsCount: or just book it while you can? While you only take miniscule fall damage
column16: you'll be cursing yourself each time a missed jump forces you to reclimb a ladder
column17: burning precious seconds.\n\nAs you might be familiar from games like The Binding of Isaac
column18: RoR features a plethora of items to be found. Most of these apply some kind of passive bonus to the character like a better chance for critical hits
column19: a bonus to regenerating health
column20: or a small demon in a jar that might cause enemies to explode when you kill them
column21: you know
column22: standard stuff. Others occupy the fifth slot in your inventory to be activated at will
column23: usually with a tremendous cool down period before you can use it again. These are your typical screen-clearing bombs and the like
column24: as well as more esoteric (and deceptively powerful) options like a Repair Kit that will instantly fix up any drones on the screen.\n\nAnd much like Isaac
column25: part of the fun of the game is watching the strange transformation these items will wreak upon your tiny spaceman. You start as a small blip of pixels
column26: a little speck that seems hopelessly outmatched by the towering wildlife and monstrous aliens. But all of that can change with a few lucky item drops. Wreathed in barbed wire
column27: encircled by a fleet of drones
column30: and leaving a trail of fire at your boots
column31: you may not even recognize your little explorer by the time you reach the final stage.\n\nThere are additional character classes to unlock. While you start with only the standard Commando in his adorable bubble-dome
column32: it doesn't take long to expand the selection.\n\nEach character naturally promotes a unique style of play with their skills. The Mercenary and Miner feature agile fast moving attacks that double as dodging manoeuvres
column33: encouraging you to keep it hopping. The mechanical HAN-D robot on the other hand has a suite of moves designed to keep him in the thick of battle. An Overclock boost increases his speed and power and can be extended by pounding multiple enemies. His brawling prowess is complemented by an array of seeker drones that can autonomously fly off and leech back health from the enemy while he fights
column34: and so on. Learning how to best utilize each character's tools and abilities is essential if you hope to weather the storm.\n\nMultiplayer gives the individual characters a little more room to breathe and express themselves. Some of the more idiosyncratic classes that I thought were a bit lacklustre in single player came into their own with a team. I was worried that adding more players to the recipe would spoil the difficulty of the game. This is definitely not the case. While the extra firepower and the ability to split up and search for the exit certainly makes the early stages easier
column35: having to share the loot and gold among 2-4 people means none of you will become the fearsome blackhole of alien destruction you might be used when hogging every trinket for yourself. By the final stages you'll need to work together as best you can to manage the laughably unfair hordes of nearly invulnerable monsters.\n\nWhile playing with random strangers results in the typical mad scramble of greed you might be used to in something like Borderlands – where every player jumps on every item they can in a micro-demonstration of the Tragedy of the Commons – playing with a coordinated group raises the game to the next level. When you can actually coordinate who gets what items based on what they need or what would be most useful for a particular cast member

to feeling like it's the way the game is MEANT to be played.

Which is why it's such a shame that it is absolutely broken.

Connecting to an online game in Risk of Rain gave me some wonderful flashbacks of the late-90's. Eschewing any kind of server browser or quick-game connection UI

reviewText:
Fun and addicting game, often found that I lost track of time while playing.  You kind of get that Super Smash Bros feel with the unlockable characters which drives you to play more and each character has their own unique stats and skills to further increase incentive to get them.

There's plenty of replayability however I don't feel the game is worth the full price of $10.  There is simply not enough content to market this game at that price since there are only 10 characters and once you have all of them unlocked your only reason to play is to unlock the other power-ups that have a chance of spawning or Monster Logs for some lore on the monsters you're fighting.

I recommend this game only if it's on sale.

reviewText:
Risk of rain is a side-scrolling shooter with perma death and items you can buy from currency you gain from killing monsters. The longer you play the harder the game gets. It's simple, but rewarding. You start off with one character to choose from and start unlocking others with each having their own unique skills. As you play through the game you unlock new items.

Risk of Rain is pure genuine fun without all the excess bloat that games seem to forget these days. Especially triple A games that seem to pad out too much story and excess content that drain the enjoyment that could be had. Risk of Rain is different and it emphasizes gameplay amongst all else.

I can't recommend this game enough. It is an amazing roguelike-like and its one that i'll continually comeback to.

reviewText: Play this game. Seriously. Gorgeous pixel art, awesome soundtrack, very satisfying SFXs. At 10$ it is so worth it. It IS a roguelike, so you will be more at ease if you're familiar with The Binding of Isaac and even more so with Rogue Legacy, but with three difficulty settings it will suit you whatever your skill with these games.\nIs it hard? Incredibly. Is it fair? Absolutely. Is it rewarding? Immensely. Is it fun? You bet your ♥♥♥ it is.\nAll of this already makes it a must-play, but the fact that it has 4 player coop, local or online, is so awesome. If you have 3 friends to play this with, get ready to spend hours screaming at the top of your lungs while you and your friends barely survive a never-ending onslaught of increasingly tough enemies. I know I will.

reviewText:
If you miss 90's platformers, Risk of Rain is all you need. It's extremelny difficult and unforgiving, but when you finally manage to finish it, the incredible feeling of satisfaction will repay you for all the anger you experienced before. And it only gets better after that.

Playing with your friends makes it even better. You think that they will help you somehow? You're wrong. Their attempts of beating the game will turn out to be as pathetic as yours. The feeling that your buddies are as useless as you in the brutal world of Risk of Rain shouldn't really make you feel better, but somehow it does. And it's great.

Risk of Rain is one of my favourite platformers ever.
10/10

reviewText:
Risk of Rain has some interesting mechanics. One of them is hoarding many various items in order to survive, which seemed appealing and awesome to me.  And my oh my, was I right.
You start as a stranded, fragile and little (in comparison with other monstrosities on this planet) human. On your first playthrough you will most likely die before 10 minutes pass. Actually, you will die a lot. But with each and every playthrough you'll get better and better, collect more items, learn monsters. Eventually you'll get a good run, and this where the fun begins. You can repay the deadly fauna, mowing it down in many fashions. You are the master now.
I hope that made some sense, but it's hard for me to describe this feeling. You got to feel it for yourself.
I've played many games, but this is one of the few that capture the feeling of satisfaction really good. I strongly recommend trying this game out.

reviewText: Awesome game.  Each class has a different set of moves designed to be play different ways. There are always new items and secrets to discover giving the game a lot of replay value.  Artifacts can be found that change the gameplay adding even more fun and challenge.  There is also a deep story hidden behind all of the combat which can found by reading the item and monster logs as well as the description under the name of each boss.  Singleplayer does a good job making you feel alone while the multiplayer can get you and your friends into hilarious situations.  Would highly recommend, but I prefer using my X-Box controller over the keyboard for this game.

reviewText:
Got this game for a small price, Totally don't regret it.

-Graphics are just pixel perfect suiting the sci-fi platform space nearly any pc can run it, although the characters are quiet small.

-Gameplay: just a unfair hard game that wants you dead as soon as you enter it. It's mean unforgiving and when you need help, it throws more monsters at your face

-Co-Op got to love this extra way of playing (controller support :D:)

For everyone who liked Binding of Isaac, Super Meat Boy-ish graphics Mashed all together with a Super crate box like battle system mixed with dota like skill system + rogue-like gameplay... It's a charm to play

reviewText:
If you miss 90's platformers, Risk of Rain is all you need. It's extremelny difficult and unforgiving, but when you finally manage to finish it, the incredible feeling of satisfaction will repay you for all the anger you experienced before. And it only gets better after that.

Playing with your friends makes it even better. You think that they will help you somehow? You're wrong. Their attempts of beating the game will turn out to be as pathetic as yours. The feeling that your buddies are as useless as you in the brutal world of Risk of Rain shouldn't really make you feel better, but somehow it does. And it's great.

Risk of Rain is one of my favourite platformers ever.
10/10

reviewText: I would recommend to anyone whos likes a challenge and good things. Insanely fun and addicting. The soundtrack of this game is submersive and ominous, but the game gets really intense listening to your own music. Sound effects are retro but not annoying, you can almost feel the explosions hitting your enemies and the sounds of bullets hitting their flesh.\nI have never enjoyed the idea of perma-death but this game has opened up that genre to me, it does a great job of making you feel like ever playable charcter is different, and the speed at which the difficulty, as well as your own strength, on each playthrough provides for excellent fast-action that is really addicting. And on top of everything its online an local multiplayer!\nThe atmosphere and small shreds of story we get from this game are excellent builing blocks for a game that question the human vs. nature relationship, this is built from assumptions incredibly sparce dialogue, and the tormented thoughts of a lone survivor adrift a hostile planet. While these intriguing elements of story and atmosphere are present, they are not so in-your-face
date: rather, appearing in monster and item descriptions, these small attention to detail is immersive, interesting and not at all distracting of the core game. A perfect balance of incredibly strong replay value, and a good incentive to keep playing to unlock this worlds story, which we end up caring a lot about.\nThe graffics are very charming and pleasing to the eye. No matter what of the 10 characters you play, your are always a small  pile of about 30 pixels. Not to say that they were lazy at all, no. Rather, the simplicty and smallness of your charcter is great to look at and really makes your feel small in a world of things trying to kill you. The monsters are the same way, though they are larger than you(some very much so), they feel like true inhabitants of the world youve landed in. Bosses feel and look powerful and their deaths are satisfying. Graphically the world around you looks amazing, like the remnants of an ancient alien civilization. They really put you in concern with your characters need to survive.\nOverall, I give this game a 9/10. The reason not a perfect score is the only could use some tweaking. The difficulty, graphics, upgrades, items, collectables and secrets keep me coming back for more everytime I sit down to my computer. Never, have I put so many hours so quickly into a game that was inly $10. It was worth every cent twofold

reviewText: It's still a tiny bit buggy, but for being developed by one person in their spare time, this game is phenomenal. It's easily worth twice what it's listed for. The music is great, the graphics are sharp and interesting, the gameplay is clean and tight, and it's deeper than the ocean. The game could survive on the strength of the first playable character, but each newly unlocked character adds a whole new dimension to the excellent co-op experience. Be prepared to be frustrated, be prepared to die unfairly, be prepared to make the wrong decision and end your run early, but most of all - be prepared to love this game to death.

reviewText:
Easily one of the most entertaining games I have played. I'm not much for the Roguelike/Roguelite series and games which are similar, however I easily spent Eight hours playing with friends, repeatedly trying over and over. I took a break around 12AM EST and found myself playing it again around 2AM until around 6AM. This is a very easy game to lose track of time in, however the difficulty continually spikes whilst playing, which.. Is actually quite fun to work around.
From my gameplay experience with this game, it has promoted teamwork with item combinations between my friends and I, and I have just enjoyed every moment of it.

Pros:
- Easy to understand item system.
- A multitude of classes and characters to choose from, to figure out your own personal playstyle.
- Easy to set-up online multiplayer (Currently only usable in a Beta release).
- One of the most amazing soundtracks I have heard in gaming. After Eight hours, I still want to hear more.
- Up to Six player Cooperative.
- Continually scaling difficulty, which promotes teamwork and makes player develop new strategies.
- Item Collection, and Monster Journals. Each menu option tells you more about the items you use, and the monsters you fight.
- Intuitive Combat System unlike other Roguelike/Roguelite games.
- Combat Focused instead of Platforming Focused unlike most other Roguelikes/Roguelites

Cons:
- Port Forwarding is required for this game, and some ISP's may block the native Port this game uses. (Try using 7777).
- Game Crashes are somewhat present, and if such happens whilst gaming, your data is lost.
- Lag prevalent regardless of Ping of players joining a server.

Regardless of the Cons, I definitely would recommend this game for you. I can easily see myself playing this game for upwards of Fifty hours. The game is even on sale currently (4/5/2015) for 2.49.

reviewText:
Risk of Rain is a lot of things.
It's primarily a roguelike-ish sidescroller/platformer with addictive fast paced gameplay. It is also fun. It is also incredibly challenging. It is also somewhat new. It also very, very fun.

You have to unlock most items and classes. The class you start with is very balanced, and while it might get repetitive to play it time after time until you start unlocking more stuff, it certainly pays off as you'll find an entertaining and diverse cast of playable characters, each with their own distinct playstyles and roles.
Multiplayer is downright amazing. It can be bothersome to decide who gets to keep each item sometimes and much like most co-op games, someone who doesn't carry their own weight could easily cause your doom, but regardless, when you get a well coordinated team, or at least one with a minimal amount of synergy, it becomes the sort of experience that many co-op games strive to achieve.

If you dig roguelikes, and/or games to play with your friends, you should totally check this out.

reviewText:
Really great game. Fast paced action roguelike semi-platformer. Challenges in the game unlock new items to drop and characters to play. Collectables can be found and activated to change the game experience making the game harder or easier, depending on which ones you choose.

While there are three distinct overall difficulties, the game's primary mechanic is that the longer you play it, the harder it gets (to a point, but it's a pretty crazy point). Rushing through isn't good unless you know how to do it right, because you'll not get any items and will be too weak later down the road. Slowing down and grabbing every chest, however, will ramp up the difficulty and make the game harder too. The skill is to do both. Harder global difficulties make this in-game difficulty clock speed up, among other things.

The game has six stages, ten levels, and at least twenty level varients. Each of the first four stages can be one of two unique levels. Each level has two or three varients, one of which will contain that level's unique collectable (every level has one) After beating stage five, you can keep looping through (levels and varients can change). The sixth stage is the final stretch to the end boss and the credits roll (but it ain't easy).

In each stage, you must find the teleporter and start charging it up (90 seconds in the first two global difficulties, 120 on the third). During this time a boss will spawn, enemy spawn chances are increased, and enemies are more likely to be elites. After time is up, remaining enimies must be mopped up. You're then free to activate the teleporter and move on to the next stage.

Each character (ten total) has a unique ability set, similar to LoL or DotA. The first always has no cooldown, the last has slightly longer cooldown. Enimies drop the cash you use to open chests which contain a random item. Most items are passive, and you can hold an infinite number of them (most of them stack, usually at a reduced effect). Like usual, whites are common, greens are uncommon, and reds are rare. Oranges are usable items, and you can only hold one at a time.

Full support for up to four player co-op, local and online. You respawn at the start of the next stage. Some items apply to all people who proc them, not just the one holding it. Money is shared, no additional chests spawn, and experience is duplicated. Everyone gets XP and cash for every kill, no matter who does it.

Complaints:
No servers for this game exist, you'll need to port forward.
Game speed is tied to framerate. This is not usually and issue, as it's not an intensive game. Only if you play for upwards of an hour in a single game (a really long time) will you start to see some issues, and only then if you're computer is lame.
Game is very RNG, (it's a roguelike) so if that puts you off then this game (the whole genre, really) isn't for you.
You'll probably need to use the wiki.

reviewText:
Aahh , Risk of Rain , where do i start ...

First of all , this game may seem hard at first , but trust me , more and more you play , you will get the hang of it. This game is basically a run-and-gun with rogue-like elements. With 12 classes , each with 4 unique abilities , you wont get bord so fast. And dont forget the items , which are a lot too. The game may have some bugs , which is not nice , but you can get over them. And i almost forgot , everything is randomly generated , so no 2 runs would be the same.

Now , regarding classes , my favorite part of the game. You start at first with only 1 basic class. Yep , only 1 class out of 12. You must do certain things to unlock classes , like killing bosses , reaching a certain level or in some cases even finding the other characters hidden in the game's levels. No 2 classes are the same , each one of them has an unique playstyle and set of abilities . For example , there is the sniper who excels at firing precise shots , being very good for dealing with bosses , but not so good for dealing with hordes of enemies. Or the enforcer , a tank who can stun enemies , or block all frontal damage with his shield.

Now the items. Oh boy , there are lots of items . Some give you a shield , some make your attacks explode . There are activable items who can summon ghosts to fight for you , shoot a lot of missles and so on.

The enemies in this game are well done , every stage bringing some new type of enemy . And also , you can buy drones to help you out in your journey . These drones fly near you and shoot the bad guys or heal you.

And the soundtrack ? Pure genius.

TL;DR Get this game if you like rogue like shooters with lots of classes and items , and most of all , good replay value.

reviewText: First off, it's a roguelike - permanent death. Each play is a race against the constantly increasing difficulty timer, and whether you win or lose is heavily influenced by what the RNG decides to give you. Lots of characters and items to unlock via achievements, some easy, some stupid. If you want a game that rewards practice and learning, roguelikes are a good genre. And this is a GOOD Roguelike. It doesn't have many level layouts, so you can soon memorize them, but that works out well. Mostly the gameplay comes down to items, and the characters - each class plays differently, and this is a rare roguelike that plays well in multiplayer. I've been playing it quite a lot, and I really hope there can be more people playing this, that I can play with :D

reviewText:
now have played Risk of rain for several hours, so why not write a review.

First lets get the cons out of the way:
Enemies
The diversity of the enemies are almost non-existent, you have pew pew enemies and you have melee enemies.
I would've liked a few more enemy types

Levels
The levels get boring after a while, not much else to say about it.

Pros:
Elites
Every enemy has a chance to spawn as an elite, they get various abilities that range from shooting a rocket to healing allies.

Bosses
They're awesome

Music
Soundtrack is one of the best ever made, every level has a different soundtrack

Characters
Every character plays completely differently

Levels (pros)
Everytime you go through the portal to proceed to the next level you get to play 1 of 2 levels
this means almost every run is different

Items
Every item is useful, this means you're never sad when you get an item
(This also means that you can beat the final boss in every run)

Timer
The timer is really what makes Risk of rain original.
The concept is really simple, the longer you take the harder it gets
This means you can rush to the boss and maybe leave some items, or you can get all the items in a level. It really makes the game interesting.

Hordes
When you find the portal in a level you need to stand your ground(survive) for 90 seconds against a boss + waves + waves + waves of enemies. You can easily be overwhelmed in the normal/hard difficulty. I really like the chaos and the intensity of these 90 second boss fights.

If you like rogue-likes you will adore this game
There is almost nothing to hate, and for the small price of 9 euros (cheaper in sales) this is a must have.
I would rate this game a 9/10 however I think a dlc would make this game a 10/10.

reviewText:
This game offers a nice combination of retro platformer and roguelike, with a touch of modern video games (particularly mobas) I rate it 8/10

From an artstyle perspective, they nail it perfectly. The pixel art in the game is beautiful, detailed and not just thrown in there to give it the classic indie platformer artstyle, you can see that all the art has had lots of work go into it, rather than a lot of games that go with very simplistic shapes and objects and then pixelate them to cover the gap in the art skills of the team.

The soundscape works amazingly with the game, you truly feel like you're exploring a strange planet where little makes sense and even less isn't trying to kill you.

Finally, the gameplay. While simple and to some degree repetitive (jump, shoot, kite, repeat) it keeps it fresh with loads of different classes, all with very different playstyles. The platforming is tight, the combat is very fun and highly enjoyable, and the randomised mechanics improve the games longevity significantly. In addition, coop play is extremely fun, and probably the biggest draw of the game.

The game does lose points for the random factor though, levels, enemy 'mutators' and the item drops are randomly generated each game, but the bosses are always usually the same and the levels are very samey. This doesn't detract severely, but I feel after 2 or 3 runs, you've seen everything the game has to offer, a lot of games suffer this and it's not always an issue (e.g. Killing Floor) but I feel that the game runs out of surprises fairly quickly.

The one exception is the items, the items are the best part of the game by far, nearly all of them are unique and most of them are thoroughly enjoyable. The background lore of each item is interesting (and at times hilarious) and the craziness of certain item combos gets you hooked and wanting more. I think they did an amazing job on the item design and the pacing of how they are deployed to the player (you unlock items through repeated play throughs, granting them as potential drops for next game)

Overall, RoR is an excellent game, it has some small flaws, but in general the gameplay is excellent and the art and sound direction are beautiful. I'm hard pressed to find many indie games that compare to it's level of polish. I eagerly await future updates to the game with even more content and features!

reviewText:
Risk of Rain has some interesting mechanics. One of them is hoarding many various items in order to survive, which seemed appealing and awesome to me.  And my oh my, was I right.
You start as a stranded, fragile and little (in comparison with other monstrosities on this planet) human. On your first playthrough you will most likely die before 10 minutes pass. Actually, you will die a lot. But with each and every playthrough you'll get better and better, collect more items, learn monsters. Eventually you'll get a good run, and this where the fun begins. You can repay the deadly fauna, mowing it down in many fashions. You are the master now.
I hope that made some sense, but it's hard for me to describe this feeling. You got to feel it for yourself.
I've played many games, but this is one of the few that capture the feeling of satisfaction really good. I strongly recommend trying this game out.

reviewText:
Really great game. Fast paced action roguelike semi-platformer. Challenges in the game unlock new items to drop and characters to play. Collectables can be found and activated to change the game experience making the game harder or easier, depending on which ones you choose.

While there are three distinct overall difficulties, the game's primary mechanic is that the longer you play it, the harder it gets (to a point, but it's a pretty crazy point). Rushing through isn't good unless you know how to do it right, because you'll not get any items and will be too weak later down the road. Slowing down and grabbing every chest, however, will ramp up the difficulty and make the game harder too. The skill is to do both. Harder global difficulties make this in-game difficulty clock speed up, among other things.

The game has six stages, ten levels, and at least twenty level varients. Each of the first four stages can be one of two unique levels. Each level has two or three varients, one of which will contain that level's unique collectable (every level has one) After beating stage five, you can keep looping through (levels and varients can change). The sixth stage is the final stretch to the end boss and the credits roll (but it ain't easy).

In each stage, you must find the teleporter and start charging it up (90 seconds in the first two global difficulties, 120 on the third). During this time a boss will spawn, enemy spawn chances are increased, and enemies are more likely to be elites. After time is up, remaining enimies must be mopped up. You're then free to activate the teleporter and move on to the next stage.

Each character (ten total) has a unique ability set, similar to LoL or DotA. The first always has no cooldown, the last has slightly longer cooldown. Enimies drop the cash you use to open chests which contain a random item. Most items are passive, and you can hold an infinite number of them (most of them stack, usually at a reduced effect). Like usual, whites are common, greens are uncommon, and reds are rare. Oranges are usable items, and you can only hold one at a time.

Full support for up to four player co-op, local and online. You respawn at the start of the next stage. Some items apply to all people who proc them, not just the one holding it. Money is shared, no additional chests spawn, and experience is duplicated. Everyone gets XP and cash for every kill, no matter who does it.

Complaints:
No servers for this game exist, you'll need to port forward.
Game speed is tied to framerate. This is not usually and issue, as it's not an intensive game. Only if you play for upwards of an hour in a single game (a really long time) will you start to see some issues, and only then if you're computer is lame.
Game is very RNG, (it's a roguelike) so if that puts you off then this game (the whole genre, really) isn't for you.
You'll probably need to use the wiki.

reviewText:
Playing Risk of Rain resembles the situation in which your friend tells you to put your hands in a bowl of boiling water.
He says it'll be very hot, and you proceed to place your hands in the bowl.
This isn't hot at all!" you exclaim.
"Just you wait." he says.
Soon
date: the water starts to feel extremely hot
recommended: and you try to pull out your hands
hoursPlayed:
but they are stuck firmly.
You watch your hands melt and burn beneath the quiet water as you stare at it with horrified eyes.
"I told you it would be hot. I told you."
That's what Risk of Rain makes you feel when you play it.
More or less

reviewText:
now have played Risk of rain for several hours, so why not write a review.

First lets get the cons out of the way:
Enemies
The diversity of the enemies are almost non-existent, you have pew pew enemies and you have melee enemies.
I would've liked a few more enemy types

Levels
The levels get boring after a while, not much else to say about it.

Pros:
Elites
Every enemy has a chance to spawn as an elite, they get various abilities that range from shooting a rocket to healing allies.

Bosses
They're awesome

Music
Soundtrack is one of the best ever made, every level has a different soundtrack

Characters
Every character plays completely differently

Levels (pros)
Everytime you go through the portal to proceed to the next level you get to play 1 of 2 levels
this means almost every run is different

Items
Every item is useful, this means you're never sad when you get an item
(This also means that you can beat the final boss in every run)

Timer
The timer is really what makes Risk of rain original.
The concept is really simple, the longer you take the harder it gets
This means you can rush to the boss and maybe leave some items, or you can get all the items in a level. It really makes the game interesting.

Hordes
When you find the portal in a level you need to stand your ground(survive) for 90 seconds against a boss + waves + waves + waves of enemies. You can easily be overwhelmed in the normal/hard difficulty. I really like the chaos and the intensity of these 90 second boss fights.

If you like rogue-likes you will adore this game
There is almost nothing to hate, and for the small price of 9 euros (cheaper in sales) this is a must have.
I would rate this game a 9/10 however I think a dlc would make this game a 10/10.

reviewText: Risk of Rain is a fun, incredibly difficult rogue-like. It opens with you crash-landing on an alien planet and the goal is to survive long enough to get back to your ship. Along the way you will encounter mobs that get more difficult with time, and plenty of items. The items are worth mentioning because you unlock the bulk of them by completing challenges through the game, and they can really make or break a run. This is also a downside, as sometimes you get a bunch of healing items, but I've never played a game where I felt like I was doing enough damage, and by 45 minutes into the game weak enemies will have 2000 - 5000 hp, but you are still doing 100 - 200 points of damage. The randomness of the items does make it fun, and some runs you will get a ton of helpful/awesome items. I have yet to tire of this game, having played for nearly 100 hours. The art is fantasticly done, the music is good, and the classes feel different and varied enough. I only have 2 complaints: The aformentioned item snafu mentioned previously, (seriously, sometimes the items you get in the first stage are so useless that you'll have trouble making past the first boss) and the lack of full controller support. Having to use the mouse to select things, including my character isn't a make or break for me, but it is unfortunate.\n\nI never tried the multiplayer, so I don't know if it is good or not, but the single player is a lot of fun and pretty addictive, especially if you don't mind playing for an hour only to die and have to start over. I highly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys a challenge.

reviewText:
RoR is a platform-based rougelite where you are marooned on a hostile alien world. Collecting items to mutate your body and enhance your abilities are key to surviving the never-ending horde of incoming alien hostiles. Time is of the essence, as the horde becomes more and more aggressive as time passes.

Immediately the context is given for the game: you are alone, your goal is to survive. Depending on how you play you can be aggressive or passive in how to address the game's starting stages, but more often than not you will have to resort to running away and picking off targets before you acquire the experience and upgrades you need. Before too long you'll be strong enough to decimate colossal threats with ease -- at the aptly-named difficulty HAHAHAHAHAHA."

reviewText:
This is one of those games that you want to play for ten minutes and end up spending an afternoon on.

It's a great game, with online/offline co-op, simple but engaging gameplay (each character has 4 buttons: a standard attack and three specials with cooldowns) and permadeath. It has some roguelike elements and a very good unlock system, implementing the old standard of 'I must collect all the things' with the added utility that the 'collectibles' are actually bonuses that work for your current run.

The lore is interesting, the art is pretty, the gameplay is hard (or easy, depending on your luck in-run).

While there are unlockable characters, they are not better than the starting character, but simply different. Each new character supplies a new way of playing the game and a total change of perspective.

All in all, buy it. And if it's on sale, buy two.

reviewText:
Risk of Rain is an action platformer with roguelike elements. With permanent death as a primary feature, players will have to play their best to get as far as possible. Fight on a mysterious planet with randomly spawning enemies and bosses, either alone or with 3 friends in online co-op. With over 100 items at your disposal, you will find the tools you need to find the teleporter back home. Discover a myriad of randomly chosen stages, from the desolate forest to the frozen tundra.

The three main goals for our game are simple:

1. Design a game that is randomly generated every play-through, to keep replayability high and fresh.

2. Time = difficulty. The higher the in-game time gets, the harder the difficulty gets. Keeping a sense of urgency keeps the game exciting!

3. Be enjoyable, regardless of whether you win or lose. No more fussing with complex and non-intuitive gameplay patterns. Players should not blame the game for their loss!

''..joy comes from amassing items, gaining experience and watching your character evolve into a godly killing machine.'' - Joystiq

''This game is immaculate. The enemy design, the sound effects, the powers, the fights, all of it feels wonderful.'' - Eurogamer

..a ridiculously compelling procedurally generated side-scrolling platform survivor-me-do
date: with multiple characters to play as
hoursPlayed:
and some of the hardest-hitting deaths I've experienced in such games" - RockPaperShotgun
Key Features
Engage in local and online multiplayer with friends and other players from around the world!
Play and unlock 10 unique characters

votesFunny:
from missile drones to healing drones!

Unlock new items and characters through difficult achievements to keep the game fresh with each playthrough.
Save your best highscores and stats!"

reviewText:
First of all, let me just say that I haven't writtien a review since the the required review for the Pillar of Community Steam badge. I've always planned to write more, but I wanted to make my next one way more meaningful than the first. So, here I am.  This should already say something about how great this game is.

Risk of Rain is one of the best games I've ever played (And I've played on every platform, and over thousands of games). It blends co-op, roguelike elements, challenge, and good old fun in one, amazing, already low-priced package. The soundtrack is great; so much so that I was always stuck listening to it in my head, until I eventually took the files from within the game itself and copied them to my phone to listen to them when away from my pc.

Whether you like playing solo or going through games with a friend, you'll find there's challenge in both, no matter the skill. The game's difficulty slowly increases with time...after the 40 minute mark, you've just about hit the highest difficulty. However, if being challenged isn't your thing, you can always just choose the 'Easy' difficulty at the character screen, and difficulty will climb slower, but you won't be able to earn achievements this way. The challenge is to get farther than you did your last attempt, and to collect as many loot items along the way, to fill your logbook, which in itself I've spent many hours just reading the hidden and not-so-hidden references in the backstory of Risk of Rain. Each item has a unique effect, and different descriptions. Some items can only be found within the game after completing certain parameters shown in the logbook. New classes can also be unlocked this way.

Even if you don't like reading, and prefer just going in and shooting things, Risk of Rain will sate you. After 5 mintues into the game, you're already guarenteed to be running for your life, blasting what you can as you try and evade everything trying to kill you. Each class in the game has unique abilities, and offers different playstyles, suitable for different types of players. Personally, I like being a gunslinger, and sneaking, so naturally, I love Bandit and Commando. Commando is your basic, starting class, and is actually arguably the best class of the game, if you know how to use him to his full extent. However, that doesn't mean that your class can't be the best in your hands. Commando is only the most balanced, and a good starting point for every type of player. But as you get into the unlockable classes, you'll eventually find one that suits you, if the first few aren't your style.

The art in this game was also really outstanding, and inspiring. Pixel art isn't easy to pull off well; yet Risk of Rain's dev team did an amazing job of spinning a story within the art itself. Personally, it inspired me to do more art, and more writing. I don't think the game will ever look dated...This game could easily look as something from the 90's, yet something from any future generation with its fast gameplay, and creativity. If you appreciate any kind of digital art, you'll be lost and immersed in the game's visuals itself. This may be a little unrelated, but the soundtrack just added onto the ambience so well when enjoying this game, and the art.

All in all, the game is easily worth the money invested into it. Every game is different, no two playthroughs are the same, and your luck can be all good or all bad in any playthrough, but ultimately, you can control your destiny in the game with your skills. The game really reminded me of Dark Souls with the challenge it gives you, and the gameplay itself feels like a classic sidescroller, yet with more magic and originality than most. The game is easily a classic of its own, and I believe will withstand the test of time in this coming generation of games, and even afterwards.

reviewText:
This is one of those games that you want to play for ten minutes and end up spending an afternoon on.

It's a great game, with online/offline co-op, simple but engaging gameplay (each character has 4 buttons: a standard attack and three specials with cooldowns) and permadeath. It has some roguelike elements and a very good unlock system, implementing the old standard of 'I must collect all the things' with the added utility that the 'collectibles' are actually bonuses that work for your current run.

The lore is interesting, the art is pretty, the gameplay is hard (or easy, depending on your luck in-run).

While there are unlockable characters, they are not better than the starting character, but simply different. Each new character supplies a new way of playing the game and a total change of perspective.

All in all, buy it. And if it's on sale, buy two.
