reviewText:
I give this an 8 out of 10. The gameplay is challenging, and it keeps you deciding whether or not to be rushing to the next level in hopes of beating it faster, or exploring for as many items as possible beforehand.

The multiplayer can only be played with by friends who share their IP with you. This is one of the two flaws with the game that I have noticed. But other than that, what can go wrong with cooperative play while trying to survive together? Multiplayer takes teamwork. You cannot just hog all the items and expect your partner to survive.

The other flaw is how things work with item unlocks. They force you to either get them by going into the game and actually only trying to get said acheivement, or you just play normally and barely get any of them. The less items you have unlocked, the less likely you are to succeed at this game, so start farming those achievements!

A strong game overall with few flaws, would definitely reccommend this for anyone who likes a challenge, pick this up if you have the money. You will not regret it.

reviewText:
Risk of Rain is a slow boil that truly rewards the patient. Initially, playing the game can seem like an exercise in futility, as your character gets overwhelmed by massive odds. But slowly, as more and more items unlock and pile on, game play sessions tip the scales in the other direction, towards the absurd.

Before you know it, you've got forty items, double, triple, and quad-stacked or more, and your damage dealt is measured not in tens but thousands. Lasers and missiles and explosions spew from your body with each attack, and enemies fall when they enter your immediate range. Suddenly, game play sessions that lasted 15 minutes seem paltry in comparison to your multi-hour runs, cycling through stages countless times as you run the hamster wheel of greed and mayhem.

Again, Risk of Rain rewards the patient. Slog through your failures, and ultimately you'll come out the other side, 15 hours later, with the most fun platformer in a long time.

reviewText:
This is by far one of my most favorite games of the year. It's like an old school shoot-em up, like Contra, pushed to 11.

There are currently 10 classes in the game, each with a different skillset, so you should find one you are comfortable with. The classes range from a sniper who can one-shot bosses under the right circumstances, a riot officer who can plant his shield on the ground to absorb all damage from the front but renders him immobile and an engineer who can plant turrets and mines. You unlock each class by doing various objectives like beating the game or doing a mini event.

Each class has four different abilities. You start out with the Commando who is very very good and is one of the best in my opinion (but I like the Huntress more). His primary damaging ability (spammable) is dual shot which fires two shots for damage,  a railgun like ability that fires a straight shot piercing all enemies, a dodge roll that gives you invulnerability frames, and an ability that can fire in both directions for quite a bit of damage. The overall combat in the game is very satisfying and if you die you know it was your fault and not the games. The game also has native 360 pad support, which is what I use to play, not so sure on the ds3 pad support though.

There is a selection of active items you can pick up that can do some pretty cool things like summon some backup drones or summon a shadow clone to mimic your abilities. There are also many passive items you can get that give you various bonuses like enemies drop meat cubes on death that heal you when you pick them up, every 4th basic attack will pierce and summon bolts after you kill an enemy that will seek out others and damage them.

The difficulty in the game can range from easy to holy ♥♥♥♥ this is the worst thing in the world, it really all depends on the items you get in the game. You can get some insane items on the first stage that can carry you through the rest of the game, like Infusion which grants maximum health on each kill or 56 Leaf Clover which makes farming much easier as it makes elite mobs, ones that have a white border around their health bar, have a chance to drop items.

The level variety is really nice as they include a snowy levels, lava levels, underwater levels (no drowning involved!), and a space ship. There is also a hidden level in the game, can you find it without looking it up? The levels in the game are procedurally generated meaning that there will never be a chest inside a wall or the teleporter to exit each stage isn't inaccessible.

The soundtrack in the game is just amazing, that's all I can say. Go listen to it for yourself! My favorite track is http://youtu.be/iSnOWqTPUNQ. If you want throw your money at Chris Christodoulou for this amazing soundtrack at http://chrischristodoulou.bandcamp.com/album/risk-of-rain.

My closing words are BUY THIS GAME you will not be disappointed one bit.http://fc01.deviantart.net/fs70/f/2012/199/d/0/shut_up_and_take_my_money_by_lolikips-d34yx16.png

reviewText:
This is by far one of my most favorite games of the year. It's like an old school shoot-em up, like Contra, pushed to 11.

There are currently 10 classes in the game, each with a different skillset, so you should find one you are comfortable with. The classes range from a sniper who can one-shot bosses under the right circumstances, a riot officer who can plant his shield on the ground to absorb all damage from the front but renders him immobile and an engineer who can plant turrets and mines. You unlock each class by doing various objectives like beating the game or doing a mini event.

Each class has four different abilities. You start out with the Commando who is very very good and is one of the best in my opinion (but I like the Huntress more). His primary damaging ability (spammable) is dual shot which fires two shots for damage,  a railgun like ability that fires a straight shot piercing all enemies, a dodge roll that gives you invulnerability frames, and an ability that can fire in both directions for quite a bit of damage. The overall combat in the game is very satisfying and if you die you know it was your fault and not the games. The game also has native 360 pad support, which is what I use to play, not so sure on the ds3 pad support though.

There is a selection of active items you can pick up that can do some pretty cool things like summon some backup drones or summon a shadow clone to mimic your abilities. There are also many passive items you can get that give you various bonuses like enemies drop meat cubes on death that heal you when you pick them up, every 4th basic attack will pierce and summon bolts after you kill an enemy that will seek out others and damage them.

The difficulty in the game can range from easy to holy ♥♥♥♥ this is the worst thing in the world, it really all depends on the items you get in the game. You can get some insane items on the first stage that can carry you through the rest of the game, like Infusion which grants maximum health on each kill or 56 Leaf Clover which makes farming much easier as it makes elite mobs, ones that have a white border around their health bar, have a chance to drop items.

The level variety is really nice as they include a snowy levels, lava levels, underwater levels (no drowning involved!), and a space ship. There is also a hidden level in the game, can you find it without looking it up? The levels in the game are procedurally generated meaning that there will never be a chest inside a wall or the teleporter to exit each stage isn't inaccessible.

The soundtrack in the game is just amazing, that's all I can say. Go listen to it for yourself! My favorite track is http://youtu.be/iSnOWqTPUNQ. If you want throw your money at Chris Christodoulou for this amazing soundtrack at http://chrischristodoulou.bandcamp.com/album/risk-of-rain.

My closing words are BUY THIS GAME you will not be disappointed one bit.http://fc01.deviantart.net/fs70/f/2012/199/d/0/shut_up_and_take_my_money_by_lolikips-d34yx16.png

reviewText:
Great little game, fast, can be played in short sessions of no more than 1 hour, amazing replayability due to the random nature of items you get and very hard and rewarding experience, amazing soundtrack (can be seen and bought here: http://chrischristodoulou.bandcamp.com/album/risk-of-rain), the art style doesnt please me that much but its not bad, its competent, character model is a bit small and sometimes trhings can get very confusing when you have 300 monsters on the screen and youre shooting lasers everywhere, but still very fun

overall great games for everyone that enjoys a good challenge, the platforming is a bit weak but the focus on combat is great, every class has a kit of 4 skills, a bit like dota champions that makes them pretty unique giving the game even more replayability, also very good coop, fun, but a bit messy, if the internet of the host is not good enough it can get very laggy, and if you dont know or cant open ports on your modem you might not be able to play at all unless you use hamachi or other program

Tl;Dr: great game, would rate it 8.5/10

+great value
+great gameplay
+great soundtrack
+lots of replayability
+good selection of classes and items
-issues connecting on multiplayer

reviewText:
This game.

My god.

People play games like Binding of Isaac, and I can theoretically comprehend the enjoyment they derive from such games, but I myself have never been able to enjoy them. Risk of Rain, on the other hand, has some of the same elements like character unlocking and item unlocking and stuff, but this game makes it so wonderful on an entirely new level. I cannot praise this game enough. The game has a wonderful difficulty curve, where the more time you take the harder everything gets. Some people are under the impression that it stops at the highest displayed difficulty, but it keeps going.

You may feel like a god at times, but if you take too long, no matter how strong you are, you will be smacked down if you become complacent. The difficulty is satisfying and fair, and the entire feel of how you approach fights and how you do things is SO strongly correlated by which character you are playing that you can't at all approach a situtation the same way with one character as you did as another: It's an extremely unique experience.

There is an absolute ton of items in this game, all with interesting effects, and you unlock more by completing challenges with any character, or a specific one depending, and it all feels awesome.

The art style is absolutely gorgeous. It's very 2d and in a lot of ways is somewhat low-res, your character for example is entirely made up of only a few pixels. But the few pixels used in any given element are used very well, and it looks amazing in the end. The backgrounds as well are absolutely incredible, the background in either of the first level possibilities and the final level in particular are absolutely incredible.

The soundtrack: It's unfair. I feel very bad for every other developer in existence who now has to make soundtracks for their games now that this game's soundtrack is around. It's unbelievable how well this soundtrack fits the game. The music is amazing and I can't get enough of it, it's soooooooo good. Beyond even the music, the sound effects on attacks and enemies is excellent as well (with the minor exception of some spider enemies in the mid game who are a biiit too into making their sound) in that they impart a great feel for what is happening and the weight behind the attacks that you can rarely afford to let hit you.

I could probably go on for days. This game is absolutely incredible and I love just about every bit of it. My only regret is that I didn't know about it while it was in Kickstarter, so I missed my opportunity to throw money at it in development. Anyone reading this should absolutely get this game, and even get copies for friends/encourage friends to get it as well so you can all play it in co-op and be completely amazed by how good this is.

reviewText: A gem born out of the greenlight.  Platforming, shooting and plenty of unlocks while still remaining true to its roguelike roots. reviewText:
Risk of Rain has earned a special place in my heart. It is one of best games I have played in 2013 and 2014.

The game is simple Kill monster ,eared money ,sped money ,beat boss and get the hell outta of there. The difficulty of the game is tied with the time the more time you spend on your playthrough the harder the game gets.

Gameplay is simple 2D contra style. Well it depends highly on which class you pick and there are great verities of them. Every class is unique with his on Con and Pros and attacks. Took me 21 hours to finally beat the game but am not done there is lot of classes to unlock. I really want to try every class. Since every class has its own style of attacks and abilities.

Art of this game is amazing too pixaled but still beautiful. AND THE MUSIC OMG. A masterpiece it’s really is. It fits the game so well. From the first hour playing this game I instantly went and bought the soundtrack.

Risk of Rain is a 9.8/10 for me.

Ps.I have not tried to play online Or locally SO I can’t comment on that.

reviewText:
If DotA, Rouge Legacy, Terraria and the Binding of Issac all went to a secret lab and mixed their genes together to create some horrific splice clone of themselves, it would probably be hedious and die in mere moments due to the gene pool overload. But if you took conceps from all those games and mashed them together in one small package and threw it in space, you would end up with this absolutly awsome game.

Interesting and random levels? Check.
Insane and hilarious item combinations? Check.
Fun and crazy Caracter classes? Check.
Awsome soundtrack, stylish visuals and loads of personality with minimal words? Check.
A touch of mystery, even when you arent playing alone? Check.
A metric Naval Vessel full of alien enemies to satisfyingly bash, shoot, crush and blow up? Double check.

If you are looking for a fun time, both by yourself or with freinds, then buy this game.

reviewText:
I very much recommend Risk of Rain.

Simply put, there are no, truly new ideas here. Pixel art, an immersive soundtrack, roguelike elements, (such as randomized items enemies and locations) are all elements we have seen before.

Risk of Rain ; however, managages to bring all this together in a fun way. The first few games you will get beaten very hard. Theres a lot of fun in refining and slowly improving your approach and strategy to what the game throws at you. I remember feeling the same way about games like The Binding of Issac. Improvement is through iteration, yet somehow it all still feels fresh and exciting. Once you think you've got it - a new character, weapon or item unlocks and give everythign a suddenly fresh new take.

Perhaps one of my favorite things is the way items stack. Seeing the same item twice doesn't feel like you'v elost ground. Getting, say many missiles that increace the chance to fire a moarter blast can work toegher to turn your player into a mean machine, blasting rockets, bullets and mayhem everywhere. Theres is a great deal of satisfaction to unleashing a lot of carnage after an especially enemy filled screen or boss fight.

The slow and incremental increase of difficulty over time, prevents meaningless grinding. You find the game is now a matter of maximizing upgrading, destruction and treasure hunting vs level progression. Its a good formula- and it scales effectively.

I'm especially excited about the possibility of multiplayer, which I've yet to experience.

The only downside, if there is one- is that the characters you can play, while interestingly differnt, are also radically unbalanced in effectiveness. Some characters, like the huntress really compliment the nature of fighting enemy swarms, and tower over the other characters in overall effectiveness. the sniper, by contrast, I can only see being used as a fully support character, and is simply too unuseable, and therfore not fun or exciting to play. I consider these criticisms minor. I'd be much more nonplussed by playing carbon-copy characters with different shirt colors. The great variety of playable characters only lends to the games strength.

If you see this game on sale- just buy it. Its worth the money.

reviewText: Risk of Rain. A game that prides itself on being insanely difficult. Right off the bat, a red flag. But! RoR is easy to pick up, with a small set of skills that must be executed flawlessly in order to beat the game (unless you are playing Huntress. Huntress OP).\n\nThe game's selling points are perma-death (new term for arcade") and its rougelike elements. Drops and enemies are randomized
date: while the ten possible maps are stitched together out of pre-determined chunks. It has a degree of arbitration while retaining familiarity to those who repeatedly play the game. A nice balance.\n\nThe game is one of the best examples of modern pixel art that I can think of on the top of my head. It's really pretty. The movement is also very polished
recommended: with no little kinks as to how you are supposed to execute attacks--the ones you would find in games like CS:GO and Dark Souls.\n\nWhat's better yet is the game has multiplayer! PvE. But
hoursPlayed: this is where the shortcomings of the game begin. Multiple players are forced to fight over a fixed amount of item drops

reviewText:
This is the best game ever! It's so satisfying to kill monsters as they continually increase in difficulty and the power-ups are so much fun to use. I can't wait to unlock new characters and play some more multiplayer because I honestly cannot wait to play some more Risk of Rain.

Pros:

- Amazing pixel art visuals
- The soundtrack is both epic and retro
- One of the main features is perma-death and difficulty, and it gets harder the longer you survive
- Gamepad support right out of the box
- Randomized environments and monster spawns make for a different experience every time


Cons:

- It's sometimes hard to see yourself in the middle of the action after stacking so many buffs on your character
- There seems to be a bug where any Steam pop-up is increased in size ten fold when playing full-screen
- It can be a little confusing to set-up a server for friends to play in, but local multiplayer is a breeze
- Platforming can be a little wonky with a keyboard, though the controls themselves are very simple and easy to understand

reviewText: Every life gets you one step closer to beating the game.Unlike other roguelikes this one has actual progress that is not all wiped away on death. Remember to bring a friend with you and you're going to have hours of fun unlocking them.

reviewText:
I haven't played many rogue-lites myself, but I really enjoy this game's approach and its well-defined classes. Each class (10 in total) has 4 unique skills, and they allow for some fairly creative gameplay. The first skill is either a basic ranged or melee attack, although, some classes have an extra snippet tagged on. The second and third skills vary but are usually some combination of attack, mobility, or utility. The forth skill is a class's most powerful and fanciful, with the Sniper and Engineer being the only exceptions.

Similar to most rogue-lites, there is no shortage of difficulty or challenge, especially when you're 'doing it wrong'. Obtainment of items is essential, but with chests and icons (for item gambling) scattered randomly throughout maps, you must temper exploration and gold farming with efficiency, lest the game clock itself defeat you. You can also obtain hidden items called Artifacts, each possessing some sweeping gameplay change or addition when toggled. I personally won't play the game without the Glass Artifact because otherwise the items--rather than your personal ability--substantially dictate your performance.

Co-op can be a double-edged sword if one of your partners is unfamiliar with the game. They may bring more firepower, but items and gold will have to be shared. Die too much, without optimal farm, and your partner will leave you behind for the rest of the game. This is kind of what I was talking about concerning itemization.

reviewText:
Highly recommended to any fan of roguelites (Binding of Isaac, FTL, Rogue Legacy) or 2D shooter/platformers (namely Cave Story).

Absolutely wonderful game from a development team with consists of basically two people featuring a phenomenal OST by Chris Christodoulou (available @ http://bombch.us/QfL). What we have here is a tough as nails yet extremely addicting game, rewarding in every way. The pixel art is done *very*  right (and entirely by one of the two developers!) and just the right amount of attention is put into monster logs and item descriptions, with a little charm in each entry that makes collecting them that much more endearing.

Overall a fantastic experience. The fact that this may end up on sale for 5 dollars or less in the future astounds me, and it's certainly the second best time to pick up this game, the first being *right now* as it's worth every single penny.

reviewText:
This game turned to be one of my favourite games for this part of my life. It's complex and simple at the same time. Select your hero (You have just one at the beginning, but you unlock more as you play) and release mayhem anywhere you go.

The pickup system can look difficult on first sight, but later on you realize how it works and is terribly fun .

The game gets harder as you play and the more you survive, the harder the enemies are. It can be really difficult to survive, but that's the objective. And once you kill the final boss, you feel incredibly well.

On the counterpart, the frame rate is terrible in some situations that involve too many monsters. But even with that, I completely recommend it.

reviewText:
- Infinite hours and items in one playthrough? Well, it's a roguelike anyway. As long as you don't die, you can replay all the stages except the last one.
- 100+ enemies in one map at the same time... uh, perhaps 200? I didn't really count.
- 10+ simultaneous bosses. Ugh.
- The numbers above are much harder if they're elites. Especially bosses. They teleport to you, shoot red heat-seeking missiles, and shock you. Ughhhhhh.
- The hardest difficulty option isn't enough for you? Here's some artifact to make all your enemies elites, to make them all the same ♥♥♥♥ing annoying species, or to make you deal 500% damage but only have 10% ♥♥♥♥ing health.
- You could have an achievement for dying 50 times. Too easy.

TL;DR: I'm feeling dizzy. It's forcing me to play again. Help. My rain of tears aren't stopping.

reviewText:
Genre: Hectic 2-D action platformer with roguelike RPG elements
Game Time: 4~10+ hours

The game is set in the distant future
date: where space transportation is common. Space trains carry passengers and goods all across space. A particular space train
hoursPlayed: had some very special cargo. Through a series of unfortunate events
voteText:
this space train gets shot out of orbit and crash lands on a mysterious planet.. with one survivor." -From Risk of Rain Wikia

An Interesting Note

Initially the title "Risk of Rain" implies different origins. It could imply the pain from its roguelike elements or the loose plot where the cargo
helpfulPercent: which is potentially dangerous
votesHelpful: falling onto the planet like meteor showers. However according to an e-mail response from the developers
votesTotal: "…it came around as an idiom of chance
votesFunny: because the game was very chance-based… It also coincides with the chests 'raining' from the sky
commentsCount:
and our hometown Seattle."

Initial impression

Roguelike games has never been my cup of tea when it comes to entertainment. Sure they're alot cheaper and are easier to purchase
column16: but that's pretty much the only reason why I would risk spending even dollar on. Risk of Rain (as RoR) on the contrary made me thirst for more. I saw myself clicking the "play" button repeatedly and despite the length of the game
column17:
I had a great time shooting down critters and getting plummeted by Magma Worms.

"Visuals!"

Assuming you have viewed the trailer
column18: RoR is without doubt
column19: pixel-based. This is the point where a surprising amount of customers have their opinion's divided. I personally agree with what Totalbiscuit said that there could have been more done with the visuals
column20: but since the game can't get more visually neat than now
column21: I see this as an reasonable compromise. We're talking about an Indie game here after all.\n\nIn summary
column22: the visuals are clean and are easily understandable. The colors don't feel dull especially when each one of the maps are distinct. The effects are flashy
column23: and although you'll get to the point where everything goes fubar
column24: the game is fair from what you expect. Oh
column25: but them infinitely spawning Wandering Vagrants in the last level
column26: they were a massive pain in the butt. Even if you're picky in-terms of graphics
column27: getting frustrated and confused from how you died
column28:
or how you're being hurt will be the least of your concerns.

Mechanics(Contents)

Now in RoR you have plentiful numbers of passive items as well as interesting active items and drones you'll find throughout each randomized level. However what makes RoR so addictive aside from it's procedurally generated worlds
column29: are its twelve characters that create a basis of your gameplay.\n\nYou begin with the Commando
column32: a beast equipped with poison potentially lethal to even the hulking bosses of the game. Of course you will quickly create a preference on each character
column33: but you'll be inclined to come back to for a refreshing gameplay
column34: especially for Co-Op. The point that has to emphasized here is that to say the characters in this game define RoR
column35: isn't even the slightest understatement. Experiment
column36: and enjoy the variety. Most of all
column37: have fun taking down hoards of those monsters. Before you get utterly destroyed
column38:
though.

What the game offers

Over a hundred items that are categorized with rarity
column40: there are no two items that have the same effects.\nInteresting artifacts that mostly make the game hard
column41: but more interesting. For example the Hive Cluster artifact makes the randomized loot
column42: choosable. The Origin artifact on the otherhand
column43: spawns Imps and a Imp boss every 10 minutes.\nVery limited
column44: but unique maps that provide flavor and decreases boredem to the game."
